title: Anchoring in Personalized Pricing
affiliations: University of Houston - Department of Decision & Information Sciences, School of Management, University of Science and Technology of China and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Anchoring in Personalized Pricing
detail.abstract: Firms invest heavily to collect consumer information and infer preferences for price discrimination. However, decision makers often rely heavily on the first piece of information, leading to insufficient adjustments from this initial value, a cognitive bias known as anchoring. While there is extensive laboratory and empirical literature on anchoring, theoretical models exploring the impact of this bias on the implementation of personalized pricing are relatively scarce. Methodology/results: We develop a personalized pricing model, and analytically characterize a seller's personalized pricing and procurement decisions based on their information processing behavior. We find that anchoring bias reduces the likelihood of the seller engaging in price discrimination. As a result, the seller may shift from a discriminatory pricing policy to setting a uniformly high (resp. low) price in a low (resp. high) profit margin market as he becomes more biased. Interestingly, a seller with higher procurement costs does not necessarily experience lower profit. Managerial implications: Our findings offer valuable insights into the design and implementation of strategies to improve pricing and inventory decisions while mitigating executives' anchoring bias. Furthermore, the results suggest that sourcing from the lowest-cost supplier may not always yield optimal outcomes for firms.

title: Decoding Deductions

detail.title: Decoding Deductions
detail.abstract: This Article provides new insights into the federal income tax deductions available to individuals. First, after organizing individuals' deductions into the familiar categories of expenses versus losses and three types of activities that individuals engage in, the Article shows the advantages of bifurcating the standard losses category. Second, it focuses on limitations that the Internal Revenue Code (Code) imposes on deductions. It identifies two distinct types of "separate limitations" the Code uses, and it uncovers important patterns in how the Code treats disallowed amounts. Third, although the federal income tax is generally described as using annual accounting, the Article shows that the categories that individuals' deductions fall into map neatly onto annual, transactional, and lifetime-esque accounting, with limited and revealing exceptions.

title: Numerical Cognition and Behavioral Pricing: The AC-ME Framework
affiliations: Cornell University - Samuel Curtis Johnson Graduate School of Management, New York University (NYU) - Department of Marketing and University of British Columbia (UBC)

detail.title: Numerical Cognition and Behavioral Pricing: The AC-ME Framework
detail.abstract: We introduce the AC-ME framework to elucidate the role of numerical cognition in price evaluation. This framework highlights the interaction between two cognitive systems: the Arithmetic Calculation (AC) system, which performs rule-based operations, and the Magnitude Estimation (ME) system, which relies on perceptual estimations of magnitude. The AC system facilitates operations such as addition and subtraction, while the ME system enables perceptual estimates of magnitudes informed by the mental number line. Through the lens of the AC-ME framework, we provide new insights into behavioral pricing effects, such as the left-digit effect, price partitioning, reference prices, multi-tier discounts, quantity framing, the rating format effect, and the price precision effect. These behavioral pricing effects illustrate how arithmetic calculations (AC) and perceptual magnitude estimations (ME) jointly influence price evaluations. Contrary to the view that these errors in numeric judgments are irrational, the AC-ME framework posits that they are rooted in cognitive mechanisms with adaptive rationality. While perceptual estimations can sometimes cause deviations from the answers of arithmetic calculations, they play a crucial and beneficial role in everyday numerical judgments.

detail.title: Waiting for a Cause: Operational and Informational Strategies to Boost Checkout Charity
detail.abstract: As retailers increasingly embrace socially responsible practices, checkout charity has emerged as a prominent initiative to support charitable causes. This socially responsible initiative, where retailers request consumer donations during the payment process, has enabled retailers to support nonprofits in reaching broader audiences. However, it remains unclear how operational factors preceding the donation request affect consumers' donations. Understanding this relationship is critical for retailers seeking to maximize their social impact and for nonprofits facing persistent funding gaps. In this paper, we examine how waiting time influences checkout charity donations and identify strategies retailers can implement to manage this relationship. We conduct five online experiments simulating virtual queuing environments. Our findings reveal that queue management affects not only consumer experience but also charitable giving effectiveness. We find that longer waiting times decrease consumer donations by lowering consumer satisfaction. We then explore how retailers can manage this relationship through operational and informational levers. Capacity expansion increases consumer donations, while process transparency reduces donations by exposing perceived inefficiencies. Informational levers such as providing donation usage information prove effective for short waits while highlighting highly visible causes boosts donations even under long wait conditions. Our findings provide actionable guidance for retailers implementing checkout charity programs, enabling them to better support nonprofit partners while strengthening their social responsibility initiatives and contributing to broader societal welfare.

detail.title: Closing the Loop: The Dynamic Challenge of the Circular Economy of Plastics
detail.abstract: This study investigates the dynamic challenges facing the circular plastics economy in the Netherlands, focusing on the viability of recycling under current and future policies. Despite ambitious regulations mandating higher recycled content in plastic products, the industry faces structural obstacles, including low profitability, limited capacity, and quality constraints. Using a system dynamics model built in collaboration with key industry stakeholders, we explore the market dynamics of mechanical plastic recycling. Our findings reveal that policy effectiveness depends on addressing material quality and financial feasibility, suggesting that targeted, performance-based support is essential for fostering a competitive and scalable circular plastics industry.

detail.abstract: There is an ongoing debate among scholars on how to tackle disinformation. Media education initiatives to increase literacy are effective ways to counter disinformation. Hence, the European Commission (2022) published Guidelines for Teachers and Educators on Tackling Disinformation and Promoting Digital Literacy Through Education and Training. The present research looked at the role of social media literacy in increasing awareness of the role of social media in spreading disinformation. We developed an educational intervention based on the European Commission guidelines. We investigated its impact on perceived social media literacy, the intention to share fake news on social media, and general conspiracy beliefs. We conducted a within-subject (two times measurement: before the educational intervention and one week after) +1 experiment with ùëÅ = 127 young adults (aged 18 to 23). After filling in an initial survey, the experimental group received a 15-minute educational intervention on the role of social media for disinformation dissemination in complex digital information environments. One week later, all participants completed the second survey to assess perceived social media literacy and general conspiracy beliefs. In both surveys, participants saw three Instagram posts from a fictitious media outlet to express potential intentions to share on social media. Among the three posts, two showed false information. Findings showed that educational intervention produces a significant increase in perceived social media literacy and a decrease in general conspiracy beliefs. Intellectual humility moderates the impact of educational intervention on algorithmic awareness.

detail.abstract: What will be the dominant configurations in the electric vehicle (EV) market for efficient combinations of vehicle, battery, and charging systems? We develop a system dynamics model to explore the solution space formed by the relationships between these subsystems and their effects on overall system performance. Model development draws from operations management theory on resource efficiency, modularity, servitization, and sustainability. We find that an integrated vehicle-battery configuration constrains the efficient use of scarce battery materials. On the contrary, modular battery design enables Battery-as-a-Service solutions, which combine private residential charging for everyday short-distance driving and public fast charging for long-distance trips.

title: Sukuk Designs: Resolving the "Equity" vs "Equity-at-Default" Tension
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Sukuk Designs: Resolving the "Equity" vs "Equity-at-Default" Tension
detail.abstract: With respect to Sukuk structures and markets we identify two competing perspectives. The market perceives Sukuk as "Shariah compliant bonds" exhibiting a hybrid character-behaving like fixed-income debt during normal operations but transforming into equity-like positions (contingent equity) upon issuer default. We present this perspective as the Sukuk as Equity-at-Default (EaD) hypothesis. However, the Shariah academies prefer Sukuk to be treated as temporary or permanent equity clearly distinct from common equities and bonds. This dichotomy clearly leads to a tension between the Market (investor protection and default management) and the Ethics (alignment between form and substance). This tension is counterproductive for the development of Sukuk markets. To analyze and resolve this tension, we apply the Dynamic Prescriptive Economics (DPE) four quadrant framework to assess Sukuk design along two dimensions: (1) alignment of form with substance, and (2) effectiveness of distress management. The DPE methodology explains our analytical approach, combining conceptual modeling with case studies. The main analysis elucidates how sukuk confers genuine asset ownership rights that grant investors equity-like control in default scenarios, affecting risk assessment and pricing. The case studies support the EaD hypothesis and lead to the core conclusion-a Sukuk is a Sukuk because it is Equity-at-Default. We argue that the EaD paradigm is unique to Sukuk and central to Quadrant I: where the dual character of sukuk (debt-like security in good times, equity-like risk bearing upon default) is optimized, made enforceable, and designed as a practical feature-not just an academic distinction. Merely designing sukuk as permanent or temporary equity in a legal form without strong distress effectiveness or focusing only on theoretical compliance (as in the Shariah academy's viewpoint), would place Sukuk elsewhere (Quadrant IV or II). Thus, Quadrant I explicitly prefers and enhances the practical, enforceable EaD model over both pure as equity models and debt mimics. We discuss enforcement mechanisms, jurisdictional variability, and practical hurdles that can undermine sukuk holders' rights. Finally, the paper offers Conclusion and Recommendations for market development and legal reforms to enhance sukuk's unique value proposition-aligning Shariah principles with economic substance and strengthening investor protection in defaults. This forward-looking roadmap advocates for innovations in sukuk structuring, standardized legal frameworks, and adaptive strategies (Substitution, Transformation, Offsets) to transition sukuk from their current form-dominant model toward a robust risk-sharing paradigm.

detail.abstract: This research investigated the possibility of enhancing senior secondary school students' academic performance irrespective of gender in analytical chemistry concept using Collaborative-Predict-Explain-Observe-Explain (CPEOE). The study adopted a quasi-experimental research design. Analytical Chemistry Attention Inventory (ACAI) and Analytical Chemistry Performance Test (ACPT) were the instruments used for data collection. Cronbach Alpha was used to ascertain the reliability index of ACAI which gave reliability value of 0.87. The internal consistency of ACPT was tested using Kuder-Richardson (KR-21) formula which yielded a reliability value of 0.96. The population was 7,152 SS2 students offering chemistry in Makurdi, Benue State, Nigeria. A sample of 157 students drawn from 3 schools in Makurdi Local Government Area of Benue State, Nigeria was selected using multi-stage sampling techniques. Four research questions and four null hypotheses guided the study. The research questions were answered using Mean and Standard Deviation scores while the null hypotheses were tested at 0.05 level of significance using results from Analysis of Covariance (ANCOVA). The study revealed among others, that there was no significant difference between the mean attention rating of male and female students taught analytical chemistry {F1, 78 = 1.020, P>0.05}. It was also revealed that that there is no significant difference between the mean academic performance of male and female students taught analytical chemistry using CPEOE {F1, 78 = 4.890, P>0.05}. It was recommended among others that since CPEOE is not gender sensitive. Hence, both male and female students should be involved in CPEOE classroom to enhance their attention and academic performance in analytical chemistry. Serving teachers should be encouraged to use CPEOE in teaching analytical chemistry concepts.

detail.abstract: The dairy sector in India plays a pivotal role in rural development, offering income and livelihood opportunities, particularly for marginal communities. This research paper explores the contribution of dairy value chains in enhancing the socioeconomic conditions of marginalized communities in Rajasthan. Using primary data collected through surveys, interviews, and focus group discussions across select districts, the study critically analyzes how dairy production, processing, and marketing impact income generation, social inclusion, and economic mobility. Policy recommendations are provided to strengthen dairy value chains for inclusive rural development.

title: I need a network: determinants and real effects of bond roadshows *
affiliations: University of Zurich, University of Zurich - Department of Business Administration and University of Zurich

detail.title: I need a network: determinants and real effects of bond roadshows *
detail.abstract: Equity roadshows are a well-studied phenomenon, and the literature has found that their primary purpose is to reduce information asymmetry and underpricing. However, little is known about the determinants and real effects of bond roadshows. This paper examines why firms decide to conduct a roadshow when issuing bonds and their real effects on the cost of bonds-a literature gap possibly due to a lack of readily available data, which we had to manually collect. We conduct surveys with underwriters and issuers to gain their insights on the role of bond roadshows and obtain two conflicting answers: according to underwriters, bond roadshows have an informational role, while according to issuers, they have a marketing role. We test these opposing views in the German bond market (2014-2023), finding evidence in support of the marketing role. We show that bond roadshows aim to raise investors' attention and increase their demand in the primary market, possibly to establish a network of institutional investors. The different role that bond roadshows have compared to equity roadshows underscores the importance of closing the literature gap and studying their real effects. We test and find that bond roadshows reduce the cost of bonds for firms, reducing bonds' final spread and substituting for the need for underpricing to ensure successful issuance. These findings offer novel insights into the role of the investors' networks in bond markets, highlighting how roadshows influence capital-raising outcomes.

detail.title: From Ideals to Institutions: Transaction Costs, Centralization, and Public Choice in Decentralized Autonomous Organizations
detail.abstract: Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs) are often portrayed as exemplars of disintermediated, democratic governance, but research suggests this is a myth. We build on that research using data from Boardroom through 2025. We introduce a novel measure of coordination intensity by mapping each DAO's mission to O*NET task importance scores. We find no direct relationship between task complexity and baseline governance centralization. Differences-indifferences estimators are used that leverage the release of advanced Large Language Models (LLMs) in late 2022 as a natural experiment. The introduction of information-processing technology led to a 31% decrease in direct participation in highcomplexity governance decisions. We argue this reflects the emergence of AI-assisted "governance specialists" who lower the cost of becoming trusted delegates, accelerating a shift from direct to representative democracy within DAOs. Rather than democratizing participation, LLMs appear to have facilitated functional specialization and delegation.

title: The Waxing and Waning of Administrative Tax Assistance
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: The Waxing and Waning of Administrative Tax Assistance

keywords: assistance in the collection of foreign tax debts

detail.abstract:
This paper analyzes countries' real commitment to administrative tax assistance under the Multilateral Convention on Mutual Administrative Assistance in Tax Matters (MAAC). The authors find that despite the MAAC's growing number of signatories, its effectiveness is undermined by countries using reservations to opt out of key provisions.

The analysis highlights several "cracks" in the MAAC's framework. First, the convention does not establish a universal legal ground for assisting in the collection of foreign tax debts, with 48% of assessed countries having full reservations. The study notes that 75% of the top 20 financial secrecy jurisdictions use this reservation, highlighting it as a characteristic of a tax haven. Second, the MAAC's exchange of information is not universal, as countries can opt out of exchanging information on "non-compulsory taxes," such as those on wealth or digital services. This is especially problematic for enforcing digital services taxes, as major digital hubs like the United States have opted out of such provisions.

Finally, the paper reveals a low and inconsistent uptake of the new Multilateral Competent Authority Agreements (MCAAs) for automatic exchanges of information on crypto assets and digital platforms, leading to a "patchwork of country commitments." The authors conclude that these flaws make the MAAC poorly equipped to address modern tax evasion and avoidance challenges, and they suggest that the ongoing negotiations for a United Nations Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation (UNFCITC) present a crucial opportunity to create a truly universal and effective regime for administrative tax assistance.

detail.title: Rewarding Nominal Growth: Unintended Impacts of Tax Cuts in Iran
detail.abstract: We study a policy in Iran that grants tax cuts to firms experiencing growth above a specified threshold. Using the universe of Iranian corporate tax returns from 2013 to 2022, we employ the bunching method and find that firms increase their reported taxable income growth by 1.17 percentage points for every 1 percentage point reduction in the corporate tax rate. Additionally, event-study results show that this growth corresponds with a reduction in the share of reported exemptions by firms. Evidence suggests that the increase in reported growth is driven by over-reporting of income and inter-temporal income shifting to maximize tax reductions. We further document evidence of information frictions: firms with ownership links are significantly more likely to coordinate their bunching behavior, suggesting that information about optimal tax responses diffuses through business networks. These patterns point to informational barriers as an important constraint on firm-level optimization in response to tax policy.

detail.abstract: This study examines whether reforms perceived as serving the interests of political elites undermine citizens' trust in political institutions. We develop a formal model grounded in Public Choice Theory and Perception of Fairness framework, in which a politician strategically decides whether to implement a salary increase, anticipating voter reactions in terms of institutional trust. The model predicts that trust may decline when reforms are perceived to reflect political self-interest. We empirically test this mechanism using the 2009 harmonization of salaries for Members of the European Parliament (MEPs), which standardized remuneration across EU member states. Drawing on Eurobarometer survey data from 2004 to 2014 and employing an Interrupted Time Series design, we find a significant and persistent decline in trust in the European Parliament following the reform. These findings suggest that political remuneration not only affects institutional structures but also conditions perceived legitimacy through the lens of voter interpretation.

detail.title: Mechanisms of Learning in Collaborative Jobs

detail.abstract: How do workers learn from coworkers when collaboration is essential? We investigate learning mechanisms using European men's football-a setting that overcomes key limitations of linked employer employee administrative data. Unlike these datasets, we observe direct collaboration (passes between players), better estimated and frequently-updated human capital measures (transfer market values) that alleviates wage rigidity, and professional skill evolution. We confirm that 10% higher peer quality associates with 3% higher wage growth. However, we uncover previously hidden mechanisms: First, conditional on average quality, team composition and exposure to stars do not affect learning. Second, better peers reduce individual playing time, causing standard estimates to underestimate learning effects by 30%. Third, intensive collaboration with high-quality peers drives learning-one standard deviation more passes with top colleagues yields 10% higher wage growth. Fourth, peer effects manifest in learnable skills (passing, reactions) but not innate abilities (speed), providing evidence against selection bias. Finally, learning persists after job changes, suggesting genuine human capital accumulation rather than temporary complementarities. Our granular production data reveals that workplace learning depends critically on direct interaction opportunities, not mere proximity to talent.

detail.abstract: This paper revisits the issue of foreign-led and domestic-led modernisation (FLM/DLM) in Central and Eastern Europe (CEE), twenty years after the original 2004 study (edited and attached as annexe). Using a neo-Schumpeterian historical political economy perspective, it traces the evolution of modernisation models in CEE across four major periods: interwar, socialist, post-socialist, and post-neoliberal phases. The paper conceptualises modernisation as a structural pendulum, with CEE economies oscillating between foreign-led growth driven by external finance, technology, and markets and domestic-led efforts focused on strategic autonomy and national industrial capacity. Empirical cases from Romania, Poland, and Hungary, as well as sectoral evidence from the electronics and automotive industries, illustrate the persistent tensions and trade-offs between these models. The analysis shows that neither pure FLM nor DLM ensures sustainable catching-up; rather, deliberate coupling between foreign integration and domestic capability-building is essential for long-term innovation-driven growth. Drawing comparative insights from East Asia, Brazil, Malaysia, Ireland, and East Germany, the paper argues that without institutionalised coupling mechanisms, CEE risks being locked into a middle innovation trap. The paper concludes by discussing the implications of current geopolitical shifts and EU industrial policy debates for the future trajectories of CEE modernisation.

detail.abstract: We develop an Environmental Depth Index (EDI) that rates the stringency of forest-related provisions in 479 preferential trade agreements concluded by 168 countries between 1945 and 2022. Moving beyond binary presence/absence coding, the index captures depth, specificity, and enforceability through four thematic categories combined with eleven transparent weighting schemes. Panel estimates with Driscoll-Kraay errors demonstrate empirical validity: a 10% increase in annual forest-cover loss raises the EDI by 1.5% while 10% larger forest stock reduces it by 4.8%, confirming that governments strengthen treaty language when degradation becomes visible but ease commitments where forests remain abundant. Outward FDI exhibits positive association with deeper commitments (elasticity 0.138), and income effects trace the inverted-U predicted by environmental Kuznets curves. Rank correlations across weighting schemes exceed 0.996, establishing methodological robustness. Although only 23% of agreements contain explicit forest clauses, those that do effectively offset deforestation pressures linked to trade liberalization. When forest-specific provisions receive priority weighting, Europe and Central Asia achieve the highest regional scores (46 points), followed by Sub-Saharan Africa (33 points), revealing patterns invisible to simple clause counts. The index provides the first comprehensive, theoretically-grounded tool for measuring environmental ambition in trade agreements, offering negotiators a practical benchmark and researchers a versatile instrument for analyzing trade-environment dynamics.

detail.title: Lobbying against accountability: campaign spending and media capture

declarations.funderStatement: The authors thank CNPQ and Capes for financial support

detail.abstract: Voting is an important instrument to exert political accountability. However, elections and elected politicians are subject to influence from other political actors, such as Special Interest Groups. We develop a political agency model with moral hazard and adverse selection, in which a lobby uses campaign finance and the media as instruments to influence the political system. In equilibrium, the resources invested by the lobby through both instruments have a joint effect on the degrees of political selection, media capture, and incumbent discipline, which ultimately determine voter welfare. We employ our model to study (i) how special interest groups adjust their behavior to regulation and (ii) its consequences in terms of voter welfare and its components. We show that, depending on the particular instrument that is regulated, the instruments of influence might be strategic substitutes or complements. Moreover, our analysis reveals new trade-offs in regulating either campaign finance or the media. Imposing a stronger regulation of campaign finance induces both a superior selection and discipline at the cost of higher media capture, as the lobby substitutes campaign contributions by media influence. On the other hand, imposing a stronger regulation of the media leads to a lower media capture and superior selection at the cost of a worse incumbent discipline, as the higher probability of exposure through the media makes a dissonant incumbent less controllable by voters. Finally, we analyze the relevant example of campaign spending caps and black cash in elections as an application, and we discuss simple conditions under which a tighter campaign spending cap induces an improvement in voter welfare.

title: The Effect of Monetary Policy on Firms' Credit Risk Premia
affiliations: Freelancer

detail.title: The Effect of Monetary Policy on Firms' Credit Risk Premia

keywords: non-financial firms' credit risk premia. JEL Classification codes: E52

detail.abstract: The European Central Bank (ECB) has been implementing conventional and non-conventional monetary policies to lower systemic risk factors, especially since the Euro-Debt crisis of 2010-2012. However, how effective were these policies in easing financial conditions and reducing the risk premia of European non-financial firms (NFCs)? This paper examines the effect of the ECB's policies on NFCs' credit default swaps (CDSs). We collected daily CDS prices of publicly traded European NFCs to analyze the immediate short-term effects of the policy announcements between June 2nd, 2014, and December 30th, 2016. We also test the possible impact of the various policies on NFCs' CDS prices using monthly data from January 2008 to February 2018. Our primary findings are fourfold: First, the ECB's asset purchase programme announcements seem to affect CDSs on the day of the announcements and in the subsequent days. Second, these announcements had a stronger effect on CDS prices after the main public sector asset purchase programmes (PSPP) started in March 2015. Third, between 2008 and 2012 and between 2015 and 2018, after controlling for the Federal Reserve's monetary policy, the ECB's interest rate policy had statistically and economically significant effects in reducing monthly CDS prices. Fourth, some of the ECB's asset purchase programmes, such as the PSPP, had a statistically significant effect on monthly prices. These findings indicate that some of the ECB's policies have significantly cut firms' risk premiums since 2015 as market conditions improved.

title: No Country for Exposed Firms: Violent Crime and Business Performance Across Sectors
affiliations: FEA-USP

detail.title: No Country for Exposed Firms: Violent Crime and Business Performance Across Sectors
detail.abstract: Firms are affected by crime either directly, through incidents such as robberies, or indirectly, through reduced foot traffic driven by fear. This paper investigates how firms of different sectors are impacted by the indirect channel. Using a triple-difference specification and data covering the universe of firms in Brazil's most populous state, I find that the retail sector is relatively more likely to experience an increase in firm entry following a decline in local violent crime rates. Retail firms also exhibit increases in total employment and hiring. To rationalize these findings and explore potential mechanisms, I develop a theoretical model in which sectors are differentially affected by violent crime through its impact on competition and markups.

title: Towards a Faster Carbon Neutrality: Comparing Energy Transition Trends in Asia and Africa
affiliations: Dataking Consulting

detail.title: Towards a Faster Carbon Neutrality: Comparing Energy Transition Trends in Asia and Africa
detail.abstract: Going carbon-neutral has now become a global necessity to avoid risking the survivability of the world from the destructive effects of global warming and climate change. Meanwhile, the momentum of the global energy transition across countries and regions has been uneven as progress is slow among developing economies. Using a novel comparative analysis approach, the study adopted the Institution-Economic-Technology-Behaviour framework. The framework analysed the energy transition in Asia and Africa and identified points of convergence and divergence between the two regions. The study concluded that while both regions varied in energy endowments, priorities, and national conditions, they have similar goals to improve energy access and mitigate climate change. Apart from investing in clean energy projects, Asian economies are playing more participatory roles in the energy transition via investments in R&D, development of clean energy technologies and carving niches in energy-saving and low carbon technologies to generate export revenues. While African economies are overly reliant on debt-financing, Asian economies are actively generating internal financing sources to promote the energy transition. The study proposed several recommendations useful for researchers, policy makers and governments to explore more critically to accelerate the energy transition in Asia and Africa.

title: THE LESSON FROM THE UKRAINIAN CRISIS: CAN CRYPTOCURRENCIES DRIVE A SHIFT FROM POSITIVE TO NATURAL MONEY?
affiliations: Birmingham City University

detail.title: THE LESSON FROM THE UKRAINIAN CRISIS: CAN CRYPTOCURRENCIES DRIVE A SHIFT FROM POSITIVE TO NATURAL MONEY?

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No conflict of interest.

detail.abstract: This article discusses the moral dimension of money and how it is affected today by cryptocurrencies in global financial markets. Its core argument is that in the Russia-Ukraine conflict not only have cryptocurrencies proven functional to humanitarian activism, but they have also given body to a new monetary community that certifies a radical departure from classic state sovereignty underpinning fiat money. Accordingly, in this context a significant shift from "positive money" (pecunia posita) to "natural money" (pecunia naturalis) has already happened. The article investigates this shift both from a theoretical and an empirical perspective, drawing some final considerations on the intersection between blockchain technology and human-chain morality in the light of the potential rise of a new model of global humanitarian money.

title: California's Plastic Reduction Laws and Their Policy Implications for South Korea : A Lifecycle-Based Framework of Production, Consumption, and Disposal
affiliations: UC Berkeley School of Law

detail.title: California's Plastic Reduction Laws and Their Policy Implications for South Korea : A Lifecycle-Based Framework of Production, Consumption, and Disposal
detail.abstract: This study aims to derive policy implications that can meaningfully contribute to South Korea's forthcoming National Plastic Phase-out Roadmap, by comparatively analyzing the case of California, a leading U.S. state in establishing advanced legal frameworks to address plastic pollution. Under the structure of environmental federalism in the United States, California has implemented its own environmental legislation that is stricter and more innovative than federal standards, and has established a lifecycle-based regulatory framework that addresses plastic reduction across the stages of production, consumption, and disposal. This study compares, at the micro-level, the policy tools adopted by Korea and California at each lifecycle stage, and further analyzes their legal systems at the macro-level by comparing their legal structures and regulatory paradigms, their implementation and enforcement governance, and their approaches to international norms and just transition. This analysis reveals a key distinction: while South Korea's legal system emphasizes efficient waste management based on the post-hoc correction of market failures, California adopts a proactive strategy aimed at a fundamental transformation by restructuring the market itself. This approach represents a paradigm shift in the plastic lifecycle, integrating production reduction, expanded use of recycled materials, and a just transition. Based on these findings, this study proposes key legislative tasks to be incorporated into South Korea's new roadmap to proactively respond to the upcoming international plastics treaty. These tasks include establishing production reduction targets, enhancing the Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) system, mandating the use of recycled materials, and the legal codification of the principle of actual recycling.

title: Improving Food Security with Aquaculture: A Collaborative Effort to Empower Tilapia Farmers in Kemiri Village, Mojokerto

detail.title: Improving Food Security with Aquaculture: A Collaborative Effort to Empower Tilapia Farmers in Kemiri Village, Mojokerto
detail.abstract: Kemiri Village, located in Pacet District, Mojokerto Regency, has significant fisheries potential but faces various obstacles such as limited technology adoption, management skills, and suboptimal market access. Through a community service initiative involving teachers, lecturers, students, practitioners, researchers, and the active participation of the community and local partners, this program is designed to strengthen the capacity of tilapia farmers to support village food security. The approach used includes problem identification through focus group discussions, training on environmentally friendly aquaculture technology innovations, and mentoring in the implementation of a fishery business management system. This activity also integrates digital marketing education and training in independent feed production using local ingredients. Periodic evaluations are conducted to measure skill improvements, production efficiency, and the economic impact on farmers. The program results show improved fish farming skills, reduced production costs, and significant increases in yields. Furthermore, it has formed a more empowered farmer group with access to a wider market. The multi-stakeholder synergy within this program has proven effective in addressing various local challenges and promoting sustainable development, with the ultimate goal of improving the well-being of the Kemiri Village community.

detail.abstract: Increasing environmental crises due to climate change calls for bridging the research and operational logics of spatial planning and humanitarian response. This article explores how long-term spatial planning and shortterm humanitarian responses relate to three facets of uncertainty that are particularly relevant in developmental contexts, namely epistemic uncertainty, ontic uncertainty, and ambiguity. The authors explore these facets through a case study of uncertainty, that of unexpected monsoon floods in 2018 and 2019 in Wayanad, a peri-urban hill district in Kerala, India. Through the case, they show that compounded uncertainty leads to ambiguity in action, but that this ambiguity can be ameliorated by a contextualised contingency planning approach. The authors conclude the article by outlining the approach in spatial planning that prioritises flexible and adaptable decision-making to enhance iterative organisational learning and action, as well as cross-sectoral dialogue to deal with uncertainty.

title: The Fiscal Impact of Peace: Evidence from the PDET Municipalities in Colombia
affiliations: Escuela de Econom√≠a, Finanzas y Gobierno, EAFIT

detail.title: The Fiscal Impact of Peace: Evidence from the PDET Municipalities in Colombia

declarations.funderStatement: Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation (NORAD)

detail.abstract: Can negotiated peace settlements promote fiscal capacity in post-conflict countries? We explore this question in the context of the 2016 peace agreement in Colombia after which more than six thousand insurgents collectively demobilized and a series of peace zones were created. Leveraging the uneven implementation of the peace agreement programs, we estimate their impact on fiscal outcomes using a "difference-in-discontinuities" design. We find that municipalities selected to be recipients of programs increased their local revenues compared to similar neighboring noneligible municipalities. In particular, local revenues in the form of property taxes increased significantly. The effect on the extensive margin in the case of property tax revenue is approximately 30\%. We find a similar, albeit smaller, impact on total expenditures, and this is associated with a differential increase in fiscal deficits. We do not find an impact on other sources of funding, such as capital revenues or fiscal transfers from the central government.

title: On a Deceptive Intersection: Data Subjects' Rights and Labour Protection. Building the Labour Scope of Data Protection
affiliations: University of Groningen - Faculty of Law

detail.title: On a Deceptive Intersection: Data Subjects' Rights and Labour Protection. Building the Labour Scope of Data Protection

keywords: Right(s) Beyond the Individual. Privacy Regulation in Contemporary Workplaces Labour-wise Data Protection

publicationDetails.detailsText: Paper presented at 6th Labour Law Research Network Conference, Warsaw, Poland

detail.abstract:
The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR, EU Reg. 2016/679) grants several individual rights and principles to the employee: information, purpose limitation and consent are cornerstones for a lawful data processing by the data controller (the employer). As a result of the widespread use of employee digital surveillance, the sphere of control and protection over the data subject's personal information has been transposed by mainstream labour law literature as a counterbalance to the new digital authority of the employer.
Yet, the new data-intensive systems such Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the Internet of Things (IoT) are still perpetrating ‚Äòone-way mirror‚Äô effects in workplace surveillance, with significant externalities on social rights such as trade union rights or equal treatment; in addition to the doubts raised by data protection authorities on the effectiveness of freely given consent in subordinate employment. From these premises, the present contribution aims to highlight the deceptive application of data subjects' rights in the guises of labour rights to protect fundamental freedoms at work. The recent literature has in fact questioned the threshold of transparency and purpose limitation ensured by individual rights regimes in curbing the impact of such surveillance on employees' rights. The contemporary data processing requires a regulatory approach that ‚Äì besides personality rights ‚Äì addresses the scope of data protection at work according to the proper function of labour regulation: interfering in the (data) market for a proper balance between economic needs and fundamental labour rights.
To this end, the present contribution classifies the three relevant intersections between data and labour protection in the existing regulatory framework: the rights of the data subject (Art. 12-22 GDPR); social consultation and data processing (Art. 88 GDPR); data protection impact assessment (Art. 32-35 GDPR, Proposal for an AI Regulation). Reasoning from the available literature, legislation and case law, this paper shows how the GDPR can be receptive to the purposes of labour regulation through a systematic application of impact assessments and social consultation. The legality and legitimacy of data processing at work ought to be shaped through collective bargaining and impact assessments, thus preventing the sphere of labour protection from being channelled only through the individual rights of the data subject. Informing data protection principles with labour-oriented ones, thus, overcomes the deceptive labour protection offered by the individual rights of data subjects in the times of AI and IoT, laying the foundations to build the labour scope of data protection.

title: The Cost of Investor Protection: Bank Loan Contracting During SEC Investigations
affiliations: City University of Hong Kong (CityU) - Department of Accountancy, Lingnan University and Memorial University

detail.title: The Cost of Investor Protection: Bank Loan Contracting During SEC Investigations
detail.abstract: In examining the loan contracting implications of SEC investigations, we document that banks charge higher loan spreads when borrowers are under investigation, with the rise in interest rates varying predictably with lender characteristics. Further, our evidence implies that the debt pricing impact of SEC investigations is amplified for borrowers suffering worse credit quality and information asymmetry as well as those relying more on bank loans. These findings suggest that banks perceive increased risk for borrowers under SEC scrutiny while also leveraging their knowledge of the investigations to extract rents. Supplementary analyses reveal tighter non-spread loan terms and a higher likelihood of amending existing loan contracts during SEC investigations. Additionally, the tightening of loan terms reverses for investigations that conclude without enforcement actions. Overall, our research identifies an economic cost of SEC investigations and alerts regulators to these costs when deciding whether to launch an investigation.

affiliations: University of Groningen - Faculty of Law

detail.title: Governing data, governing technology? Complementary approaches for the future of work

publicationDetails.detailsText: Global Workplace Law and Policy Blog

detail.abstract: An employer today can learn about interactions among employees or with customers via sensors and a vast variety of softwares. Is the tone of voice friendly enough with customers? How much time is spent on emailing or away from the assigned desk? Scores, ‚Äòidle‚Äô or silent buttons, are making the workplace a place where data is constantly accumulated and processed through Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the Internet of Things (IoT). Breaks can lead to penalties, from reduced bonuses to more serious sanctions. These are just examples that represent strong evidence in the labour law debate: the recourse to data is changing organisational models and increasing employers‚Äô capability to monitor the workforce. Thus, the self-determination and purpose limitation principles offered by the current General Data Protection Regulation (EU Reg 2016/679) are now standing under the magnifying glass: can they preserve the order of powers in subordinate employment that datafication is disrupting? Or does guaranteeing individual rights against a vast and complex surveillance society risk creating an unequal David-and-Goliath conflict?  This contribution suggests that data protection law at work is and will be crucial in ensuring labour protection in datafied workplaces. The present focus, however, is dominated by AI and IoT needs to be complemented with the governance of technologies (thus not only of data flows) that place structural limitations on employees‚Äô fundamental freedoms. A complementary approach that can be already recognised in the European Commission‚Äôs Industry 5.0 strategy, with the proposal for a regulation on artificial intelligence as one of the main (yet problematic) developments.

title: Income Inequality and Bank Credit Supply: A THANK(ful) Approach
affiliations: Mount Allison University - Department of Economics

detail.title: Income Inequality and Bank Credit Supply: A THANK(ful) Approach
detail.abstract: While pre-tax income in the middle and top of the distribution is relatively stable over the business cycle, income at the bottom is strongly procyclical. As a result, income inequality is countercyclical. Since bank credit supply has been shown to play an important role over the business cycle, this paper asks: Do shifts in the supply of bank credit contribute to the observed cyclical fluctuations in income inequality? Using an estimated bank credit supply shock based on Bassett et al. (2014), I find that, first, a tightening of bank lending standards leads to a rise in income inequality due to a larger decrease in income at the bottom of the distribution relative to the middle and top. Second, compared to total factor income (TFI), labor income at the bottom of the distribution contracts more following the tightening of bank lending standards. As a result, labor income inequality rises by more than TFI inequality. Third, bank credit supply shocks account for a nontrivial amount of the cyclical variation of income inequality. Depending on the specification and inequality measure, bank credit supply shocks can account for up to 42% and 33% of the volatility of labor income inequality and TFI inequality, respectively. To rationalize these observations, I build a tractable heterogeneous agent New Keynesian (THANK) model with an income-skill complementarity among households: i.e., 'poor' hand-to-mouth households supply unskilled labor, while 'rich' unconstrained households supply skilled labor. Firms require a bank loan to pay their labor wage bills in advance of production. When the representative bank reduces its supply of credit to firms, the cost of borrowing rises, leading to a fall in labor demand of both skilled and unskilled workers. However, since it is costly for firms to adjust their skilled labor, firms optimally choose to cut their unskilled workforce by more. The result is a rise of income inequality as 'poor' households lose a larger share of income relative to the 'rich' households.

title: The Relationship between Entr√©e Variety and Student Participation in School Lunch

detail.title: The Relationship between Entr√©e Variety and Student Participation in School Lunch
detail.abstract: In the United States, about 40 percent of students choose not to participate in the National School Lunch Program. Offering more food choices at lunch may be one way to boost participation. We used longitudinal administrative data on 135,229 New York City grade 9-12 students, their schools, and school lunch menus for Fall 2016 to examine the link between the number of entr√©es offered and participation, and to explore whether the relationship varied by entr√©e type. We proxied for type by categorizing entr√©es as vegetarian, containing beef, or containing poultry-features observable, and plausibly important, to students. We also examined the moderating effect of universal free meals (UFM), an increasingly prevalent policy that is known to affect students' lunch participation decisions. We found evidence that the type of entr√©es offered were more important for participation among students than their number overall, and that students in UFM schools were more likely to be responsive to both the number and type of entr√©es available. These results suggest that investments in the types of entr√©es served rather than their number, and/or eliminating the cost of school meals to students, may have a larger impact on participation.

detail.title: High risk aversion Merton's problem without transversality conditions
detail.abstract: This paper revisits the classical Merton portfolio choice problem over infinite horizon for high risk aversion, addressing technical challenges related to establishing the existence and identification of optimal strategies. Traditional methods rely on perturbation arguments and/or impose restrictive conditions, such as large discount rates and/or bounded strategies, to ensure well-posedness. Our approach leverages the problem's homogeneity to directly solve the associated Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation and verify the optimality of candidate strategies without requiring transversality conditions.

title: Once Upon a Time: Introducing the Historical Values Survey

detail.title: Once Upon a Time: Introducing the Historical Values Survey
detail.abstract: This article introduces the Historical Values Survey. It contains information on historically prevalent values and norms encouraging cooperation, altruism, work ethic, entrepreneurship, tolerance, but also discrimination and the challenging of authority. Information on values and norms is elicited from more than 27,000 folk narratives relying on a Large Language Model. The Survey contains 36 variables and covers up to 172 countries. Folk narratives, such as legends and fairy tales, are transmitted from generation to generation virtually unchanged and thus constitute an excellent source for historically prevalent values and norms and for culture more broadly speaking. Including the values and norms into an economic growth model documents the relevance of culture for economic development.

title: All Quiet on the Fiscal Front? Off-Balance-Sheet Fiscal Agencies in the German War Economy, 1914-1918

detail.title: All Quiet on the Fiscal Front? Off-Balance-Sheet Fiscal Agencies in the German War Economy, 1914-1918

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No conflict of interest.
declarations.funderStatement: Steffen Murau acknowledges funding by Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (German Research Foundation, DFG) for the Emmy Noether Research Group entitled ‚ÄúThe Political Economy of Financing Large-Scale Transformations. Off-Balance-Sheet Fiscal Agencies in Wars, Reconstruction, and the Green Transition‚Äù (OBFA-TRANSFORM) carried out at Global Climate Forum and Freie Universit√§t Berlin (project number 499921148).

detail.abstract: It is an established narrative in the literature that the German Empire financed World War I through an extensive issuance of sovereign debt with support of the central bank, the Reichsbank. Indeed, the sovereign debt burden of the Reich and the states combined increased from around 5 billion marks in 1914 to approximately 156 billion Marks in 1918 at the end of the war. Despite these staggering numbers, an understanding of war finance that merely focuses on the balance sheets of the treasury and the central bank cannot provide an accurate picture, as it misses out on the paramount role that off-balance-sheet fiscal agencies (OBFAs) played at the time. In this paper, we trace the activities of six types of OBFAs along three stages of the war finance operations from Summer 1914 to November 1918. First, the Seehandlung was Prussia‚Äôs state-bank that acted as market maker for sovereign debt, stimulated expansion and helped with funding throughout the war. Second, the Darlehnskassen (Loan Funds) were sub-balance sheets of the Reichsbank that supported expansion of the war economy by issuing Darlehnskassenscheine as a parallel currency and acted as market-maker for sovereign debt. Third, Kriegskreditbanken (War Credit Banks) were financial institutions that played an important role in the expansion phase of the first two months of war. Fourth, Kriegsgesellschaften (War Societies) were private sector institutions that became increasingly entangled with the state during the war and operated at an accelerated pace in the third stage as the war economy increasingly faced shortages. A similar dynamic was exhibited, fifth, by state-owned enterprises. Finally, industrial associations played an important role in the governance of the German war economy. To carve out the role of OBFAs in the war finance activities, we reconstruct the monetary architecture of the German war economy and translate the activities of the treasury, the Reichsbank, and key OBFAs into flow charts that analytically distinguish between initial expansion and long-term funding. By unpacking the role of OBFAs rather than the treasury‚ÄìReichsbank dyad commonly emphasised in financial historiography, we extend the Critical Macro‚ÄëFinance perspective into the realm of early‚Äëtwentieth‚Äëcentury war finance.

title: Dam Management in the Era of Climate Change
affiliations: Universit√† di Bologna, Universit√© d'√âvry, University of Pisa - Department of Economics and Management and Tunis El Manar University

detail.title: Dam Management in the Era of Climate Change
detail.abstract: Climate change has a dramatic impact, particularly by concentrating rainfall into a few short periods, interspersed by long dry spells. In this context, the role of dams is crucial. We consider the optimal control of a dam, where the water level must not exceed a designated safety threshold, nor fall below a minimum level to ensure functionality and sustainability for for the outgoing river. To model dry spells and intense rainfall events, commonly referred to as water bombs, we introduce a Hawkes process, a well-known example of a self-exciting process characterised by time-correlated intensity, which endogenously reproduces the concentration of events. The problem is formulated as an optimal switching problem with constraints. We establish existence results and propose numerical methods for approximating the solution. Finally, we illustrate the main achievements of this approach through numerical examples. The main and counterintuitive result of our numerical analysis is that the optimal water level inside the dam increases with the self-exciting parameter. This result shows that, when facing the dilemma of managing the opposing risks of dam overtopping and dry spells, the former ultimately dominates the latter. In conclusion, dams will increasingly lose their role as water reserves and take on a greater role in flood protection.

title: Import Competition and Productivity of U.S. Fruit and Vegetable Farms
affiliations: Virginia Tech and Texas Tech University

detail.title: Import Competition and Productivity of U.S. Fruit and Vegetable Farms
detail.abstract: U.S. imports of fruits and vegetables (FV) increased from $2.7 billion in 1990 to $29.4 billion in 2022, but few studies have assessed the impact of this rising import competition on U.S. FV farms. This study provides the first analysis of how import competition affects total factor productivity (TFP) of U.S. FV farms, using farm-level data from the Census of Agriculture for 2007, 2012, and 2017. Employing an instrumental variables strategy that leverages exogenous supply shocks to address endogeneity, we find that a 100-percentage-point increase in import competition raises FV farms' TFP by 1.1%. This productivity gain stems from the exit of less productive farms and TFP growth among surviving ones. Heterogeneous analysis indicates that larger farms experience a large TFP growth. We also find an inverse-U relationship between import competition and farm-level TFP growth, indicating that farms facing extreme competition experience TFP declines. Further analysis shows that import competition reduces FV farms' cropland acreage and intermediate input expenditure but does not affect capital expenditure, suggesting no increase in mechanization in response to import pressure.

detail.abstract: Inclusive urban policies and city-building practices must prioritise gender mainstreaming, but there is a dearth of research exploring how this approach can address the intersectional needs of different genders. Additionally, empirical insights from diverse contexts are necessary to gain a nuanced understanding of the ageing-in-place debate. To shed light on the global challenges of gender and ageing disparities, this chapter uses intersectionality as a theoretical lens to analyse current urban planning policies and practices. By examining case studies from both the Global North and Global South, it discusses how intersectionality can inform efforts to mainstream gender and ageing in urban planning. Furthermore, this chapter underscores the interdependencies between intersectionality and gender mainstreaming and how they can facilitate age- and gender-appropriate planning and design strategies. While promising initiatives to address ageing in place have emerged in some cities and countries, planning policies and city-building practices in many developmental contexts still perpetuate patriarchal social norms. Therefore, systemic consideration is needed to create holistic and inclusive urban environments. Ultimately, this chapter argues that applying an intersectional lens to gender mainstreaming in urban planning can prioritise the ethics of care and create age-friendly environments.

detail.abstract: In this paper, we focus on malicious envy of others' happiness levels and introduce a new fairness criterion that considers how agents assess their relative satisfaction based on the ranking of their assigned objects. We propose two main notions: (weakly) rank envy-free assignments, where no agent perceives another as being strictly better off in terms of rank-based satisfaction, and ex-post minimal rank envy, which aims to reduce overall rank envy when it is not possible to eliminate it. Our findings indicate that there is a trade-off between achieving rank envy-freeness and attaining ex-post Pareto efficiency or standard envy-freeness. Furthermore, the concept of minimal rank envy is positioned between rank efficiency and Pareto efficiency. Lastly, we introduce a Random Serial Acceptance rule that produces random assignments with ex-post minimal rank envy.

detail.abstract: This study introduces a novel composite approach to nonlinear inflation dynamics in identifying historical inflation patterns and forecasting future regime shifts. Assuming inflation‚Äôs responsiveness to its determinants varies across inflation regimes and that inflation shock magnitude shapes the dynamics, we endogenously identify distinct inflation regimes and analyze nonlinear behaviors within such regimes for the BRICS countries (Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa) and T√ºrkiye. In the first stage of our analysis, we employ a Hidden Markov Regime Switching Model combined with Monte Carlo simulations to establish high- and low-inflation thresholds. In the second stage, we utilize an ordered probit model to identify nonlinear probabilistic relationships between inflation regimes and key drivers of inflation such as unit labor costs, exchange rates, and global inflation. Our method achieves over 90% accuracy in predicting inflation regimes based on historical data. It also shows particularly strong out-of-sample performance in the post-pandemic period, outperforming the forecasts of international financial institutions. Even without prior knowledge of exogenous variables, the method anticipates regime shifts in five of the six countries analyzed for 2022 and 2023. Our approach offers researchers and central bankers a robust alternative analytical framework for managing high- and low-inflation environments where traditional linear or equilibrium-based models fall short.

detail.abstract: How do large disruptions to ecosystems affect human well-being? This paper tests the long-standing hypothesis that China's 1958 Four Pests Campaign, which exterminated sparrows despite scientists' warnings about their pest-control role, exacerbated the Great Famine-the largest in human history. Combining newly digitized data on historical agricultural productivity in China with habitat suitability modeling methods in ecology, we find that, after sparrow eradication, a one-standard-deviation increase in sparrow suitability led to 5.3% larger rice and 8.7% larger wheat declines. State food procurement exacerbated these losses, resulting in a 9.6% higher mortality in high-suitability counties-implying nearly two million excess deaths.

detail.abstract: A deterministic assignment that allocates a set of objects to some agents is popular if it is not popular-dominated, i.e., there is no other one where a majority of agents are better off. As the notion of popularity, i.e., democratic efficiency, is a refinement of Pareto efficiency, we introduce a weakly popular assignment as a Pareto assignment that is not popular-dominated by any popular assignment. We call a random assignment ex-post weakly popular if it has a lottery over weakly popular assignments. We introduce an upper-contour strategyproof rule that provides an ex-post weakly popular random assignment and satisfies equal treatment of equals and non-bossiness. Finally, we prove two strong impossibility results between ex-post popularity and fairness, in the sense of weak envy-freeness and equal division lower bound.

detail.abstract: This Policy Brief evaluates the evolving reasons for and application of the Trump administration's "reciprocal" tariffs and finds them wanting. The tariffs, adjusted most recently on August 1, 2025, were originally supposed to achieve reciprocity between the United States and its trading partners but were based on a defective measure because bilateral imbalances do not necessarily indicate foreign unfair trade practices; the methodology used to estimate the reciprocal tariffs was biased towards overstatement, particularly for countries producing primary commodities, which will have high pass-through into US final prices, and for countries exporting products with high import content. Given these defects, the reciprocal tariffs are better seen as a dressed-up anchoring ploy to strengthen America's hand in negotiations rather than credible estimates of the unfair trade practices that the United States faces. Moreover, even if reduced to 15 percent, the application of these tariffs to America's poorest trading partners would do little to reduce the overall US trade deficit but considerably harm their economic development.

detail.title: Guerilla Marketing in the Age of Digital Technologies
detail.abstract: This article investigates the effectiveness of guerrilla marketing in the contemporary digital age. Originating from military tactics and popularized in the marketing world by Levinson in 1984, guerrilla marketing emphasizes creativity and unconventional approaches over large budgets to reach consumers. While initially conceived in a pre-digital landscape, this research argues that the core principles of guerrilla marketing are not only still relevant but are amplified by the accessibility, low barriers to entry, and reach of digital technologies. The article provides a foundational understanding of guerrilla marketing, including its definition, historical context, basic concepts, and key rules. It then explores the arsenal of guerrilla tactics, categorizing them into minimedia, maximedia, and contemporary approaches like ambient, buzz, viral, and ambush marketing. A significant portion of the article is dedicated to analysing the application and effectiveness of guerrilla marketing in the digital era. It examines the role of social media platforms, the strategic use of memes, the power of generating online buzz, and the potential of generative artificial intelligence as tools for modern guerrilla marketers. Case studies, such as the unconventional Facebook strategy of a Polish funeral services company and Wendy's adept use of memes, illustrate the successful adaptation of guerrilla principles in the digital sphere. The article also addresses ethical concerns surrounding certain guerrilla marketing tactics, acknowledging the need for marketers to navigate legal and social norms carefully to avoid backlash. Ultimately, the findings suggest that guerrilla marketing is not only effective in the digital age but possesses an enhanced potential for impact due to the inherent virality and reach of online platforms. While the fundamental requirement for creativity and unconventional thinking remains paramount, digital technologies provide a fertile ground for guerrilla marketers to operate with agility, target specific audiences, and achieve significant brand awareness and engagement, often with limited financial resources. The article concludes that in an increasingly cluttered advertising environment, the core tenets of guerrilla marketing ‚Äì creativity, surprise, and impactful messaging ‚Äì are more critical than ever for brands seeking to stand out and connect with consumers.

detail.abstract: India's e-commerce has a bright future because of the country's rapidly advancing technology and changing consumer habits. The report analyses potential developments, obstacles, and trends in India's e-commerce market. It looks at how customer preferences are changing as a result of more people using smartphones and the internet-two major drivers propelling the expansion of e-commerce. The domination of internet shopping, the growth of mobile commerce, and the advent of social shopping are notable trends. It also draws attention to the industry's tremendous obstacles, which include a lack of resources, complicated infrastructure requirements, regulatory barriers, and fierce competition. The report makes recommendations about how to deal with E-commerce in India: Trends, Obstacles, and Growth Opportunities these difficulties. It also emphasises how crucial cross-border e-commerce, sustainable business methods, and customised consumer experiences are to the development and uniqueness of India's e-commerce sector. In the end, this essay seeks to steer India's future e-commerce by navigating these development avenues, resolving issues, and grasping chances. It offers vital information for lawmakers, investors seeking profitable opportunities, and e-commerce companies. The study examines not only these practices, but also the actions proposed by the company for the first half of 2025, which aim to reinforce the protection of this audience. To this end, an analysis of documentation in the non-academic press has been carried out. The results show that, despite the fact that the company has intensified its child protection policy and participation systems, there is still scope for improvement in terms of its adequacy for underage users. Finally, recommendations are presented to make Roblox and other interactive environments safer and more suitable for children and teenagers, while preserving their playful nature. At the same time, however, it is considered that data literacy among users and families is essential to raise awareness and protect personal data and guarantee safety in digital environments.

detail.abstract: The stock market reacts to free cash flow news at the time of the earnings announcement. The reaction is stronger when free cash flow is predicted to be more informative: for growth firms and firms with noisy earnings, and when the earnings announcement mentions free cash flow. Both the market response to free cash flow news and the frequency of free cash flow mentions have increased over time. Results suggest that the decision to mention free cash flow correlates with underlying firm characteristics, which have shifted over time. Free cash flow news and earnings news are generally complements, although they are substitutes when earnings are particularly noisy.

title: Is Complexity Virtuous?

detail.title: Is Complexity Virtuous?
detail.abstract: Kelly et al. (2024) show that increasing complexity in linear models, with potentially thousands of predictors, is "virtuous". Their work contradicts the dogma of model selection, including the Principles of Parsimony and Occam's Razor. They find that when the number of predictors far exceeds the number of observations, the bias-variance trade-off breaks down, the variance declines, and the Sharpe ratio increases. In the context of ridge regression, we find that very high complexity coupled with large penalty terms (excessive shrinkage) generate forecasts that converge to a rolling window of past returns. For example, we show the past twelve-month moving average of actual returns is 97.5% correlated to the forecasts from a twelve-month rolling window of random Fourier features with a large penalty. This finding is consistent with the theory of ridge regression. As the penalty term increases, the forecasts closely approximate the mean, and ignore the explanatory variables. Thus, increasing complexity does not outperform the standard ridge regression, and increasing complexity does not generate high Sharpe ratios, abnormal returns, utility gains or profitable investment strategies.

detail.abstract: We investigate how knowledge of news regarding government surveillance of social media affects behavior. Prior research documents user self-censorship through surveys and case studies, which make generalizing hard. We address this gap by using large language models (LLMs)-including ChatGPT, Claude, Llama, and Gemini-to simulate how diverse U.S. user profiles respond to knowledge of government surveillance. We design a multistage game in which LLMs act as social media users. We give them news on which they can comment and share, sometimes with and sometimes without knowledge from other news sources that the government is monitoring social media. Preliminary results show users modify their postings and the degree of change depends on each user's political leanings and the topic.

detail.title: Bridging Data Gaps in Emissions Forecasting: A Credibility-Weighted, Scenario-Interpolated Framework for Corporate Net-Zero Assessment
detail.abstract: Accurately forecasting corporate greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions trajectories is essential for evaluating company alignment with Net-Zero and Paris Agreement objectives and informing portfoliolevel climate strategies. Existing forecasting approaches-relying on simple statistical models or rigid scenario matching-struggle with sparse and heterogeneous corporate disclosures, limiting their reliability and practical relevance. This paper introduces a novel, credibility-weighted forecasting framework that jointly integrates historical emissions data and forward-looking decarbonisation targets, assigning quantitative weights based on the credibility and source of each data point, to account for its reliability. By applying linear interpolation between sectoral and regional benchmark decarbonisation pathways (e.g., NGFS scenarios), the method generates continuous, scenario-aligned Implied Temperature Rise (ITR) metrics even in the presence of incomplete or inconsistent data. Empirical analysis of circa 1,400 listed companies across multiple sectors and geographies demonstrates that the approach improves forecasting accuracy, achieves stronger scenario alignment, and exposes areas of target over-or under-ambition that conventional models miss. These results offer clear guidance for investors and regulators seeking robust, scalable, and transparent tools to assess corporate Net-Zero alignment and inform climate-related portfolio decisions.

detail.title: Liquidity and Monetary Policy with Fraudulent Assets
detail.abstract: This paper studies the role of money as a safe, fraud-free asset within an environment where asset trading is subject to fraudulent practices. We develop a New-Monetarist model with endogenous costly fraud and screening, which jointly determine the presence of fraudulent assets as well as liquidity. Without money, fraud arises in equilibrium when the costs of fraud and screening are sufficiently low. This occurs as random screening acts to relax the asset resalability constraint that normally prevents fraud from occurring. Money can substitute for random screening as a device to relax the asset resalability constraint, and thus, fraud never arises when money is valued. The model highlights monetary policy implications for fraud incentives and asset liquidity.

title: Trust, Thought, and Toil: Capitalism as an Institutional Filter on Innovation
affiliations: RMIT University

detail.title: Trust, Thought, and Toil: Capitalism as an Institutional Filter on Innovation
detail.abstract: Critiques of capitalism frequently focus on its distributive consequences or alleged social harms, often overlooking the institutional mechanisms that direct capitalist innovation. This paper reframes the evaluation of capitalism by arguing that its core strength lies in its capacity to generate innovations that systematically reduce the burdens of human limitation, namely physical effort, limited trust, and bounded cognition. Drawing on a typology of constraint-reducing innovation, I examine how capitalist institutions, through the mechanisms of profit and loss, channel entrepreneurial discovery toward solutions that expand the scope of voluntary cooperation. The analysis engages with the Theory of the Adjacent Possible (TAP) and argues that while TAP provides a compelling account of the expansion of innovation possibilities, it lacks a plausible selection mechanism. The contribution of this paper is to identify capitalist institutions as providing that missing selection function. The result is not random technological change, but a patterned directionality. Innovations that survive and scale are those that reduce the cost of coordination in large-scale societies. Contemporary cases including blockchain and artificial intelligence are examined as extensions of this logic. The broader conclusion is that capitalism should not be judged solely by its outcomes, but by its institutional capacity to solve coordination problems and reduce the burdens of being human.

title: The Misapplication of Statistical Methods in Liberal Arts: A Critical Analysis of Academic Publishing Bias Against Theoretical Research

detail.title: The Misapplication of Statistical Methods in Liberal Arts: A Critical Analysis of Academic Publishing Bias Against Theoretical Research
detail.abstract: This article critically examines the widespread misuse of statistical methods in liberal arts and social sciences research, contrasting it with the proper application of statistics in physical sciences. While statistical physics and mass spectrometry demonstrate the correct application of statistical mathematics to natural phenomena, liberal arts disciplines have increasingly privileged data-driven research over theoretical reasoning, leading to a fundamental distortion of the academic research paradigm. This bias has created a scientific culture that systematically devalues low-probability but scientifically significant events and theoretical innovation in favor of statistically significant but potentially spurious correlations. The article argues that this trend represents a departure from the foundational principles of scientific inquiry, which should prioritize logical reasoning and theoretical understanding over mere data collection. The consequences extend beyond methodology to affect the very nature of academic discourse, where theoretical contributions are dismissed as "opinion pieces" while empirically-supported but theoretically shallow work is privileged. This misapplication of statistical thinking has created barriers to paradigm-shifting research and theoretical innovation across both humanities and natural sciences.
