detail.abstract: The European Union will introduce carbon pricing for the building and transport sectors in 2027. This policy shift will directly affect household expenses in member states, including Hungary. Understanding public attitudes toward carbon pricing is therefore critical to designing effective and socially acceptable climate policies. This policy brief presents the first study to examine public acceptance of, and willingness to pay (WTP) for, a carbon tax in a Central and Eastern European country. It also analyses the impact of a broad set of revenue recycling mechanisms on support ‚Äì covering more options than previous international studies. Based on a nationally representative survey conducted in Hungary in the summer of 2022, the results reveal low public acceptance of, and WTP values for, a carbon tax, and limited increases in both acceptance and WTP when revenue recycling is introduced. All values are lower than those typically observed in Western European surveys. A unique finding is the relative popularity of allocating carbon tax revenues to health care and education ‚Äì a preference not reported in earlier studies. The results underline the importance of thoroughly considering the distributional impacts of carbon pricing and of integrating strong social elements into climate policy design. Special attention should be paid to those who support carbon pricing only if revenues are recycled. To enhance public acceptability, this brief recommends (1) cutting taxes on energy alongside introducing carbon pricing with compensation for vulnerable groups, (2) legally earmarking carbon tax revenues for selected climate and social spending in underfunded areas, and (3) improving public understanding of climate change, the benefits of climate policy, and how carbon pricing works. The findings can inform Hungary‚Äôs Social Climate Plan, due by June 2025, which could unlock substantial EU funds to help mitigate the social impacts of carbon pricing.

detail.abstract: This paper explores how supply chain pressures influence the transmission of monetary policy. At the sector level, high supply chain pressure is associated with a sharper and more persistent inflation response, with an overshoot lasting up to six quarters. I rationalize these findings using a New Keynesian model featuring supply chain frictions that reduce the effective inputs for production.

detail.title: Reimagining Decentralized University Education in Africa: Toward a Scalable Framework for Industry-Linked Learning Hubs Inspired by ALU and CSA Rwanda
detail.abstract: This study investigates how decentralized, industry-linked learning hubs can address Africa's enduring higher education challenges of access, affordability, and employability. It proposes a scalable framework combining the African Leadership University (ALU)'s multi-city model with the Community Services Association (CSA) Rwanda's district-based learning ecosystem. The study is guided by three research questions: RQ1: What systemic enablers support the diffusion of industry-linked university hubs in Africa? RQ2: What key barriers limit diffusion, and how do they vary across countries? RQ3: How can proven models (e.g., ALU, CSA) be adapted and costed for scale? (2)Methodology. A qualitative comparative analysis was conducted using 35 high-credibility secondary sources filtered via a PRISMA-adapted protocol from an initial 245 records (2010-2025). Four cases-ALU, CSA, Ashesi University, and UNICAF-were analyzed through the lenses of Diffusion of Innovation, Triple Helix, and Experiential Learning theory. Although the study relies exclusively on secondary sources, we applied light-touch text-mining in MAXQDA: policy documents were tokenised, stop-words removed, and coded with an unsupervised LDA algorithm (k = 6) to surface latent themes that triaged sources for qualitative comparative analysis; no clustering or association-rule modelling was undertaken. Visual tools-including causal-loop diagrams, scorecards, and a Gantt-style scale-up roadmapsupported synthesis. (3) Findings. Five core enablers emerged: policy alignment, institutional autonomy, Triple Helix linkages, diversified finance, and contextualized curricula. Barriers included regulatory rigidity, funding fragility, governance gaps, and digital divides. The proposed Pan-African Learning Hub Framework blends ALU's experiential pedagogy with CSA's grassroots model, enabling vertical progression from districtlevel cooperatives to regional research hubs. A three-year scale-up plan (USD 400-4,000 per student/year) suggests viability under flexible policy conditions. (4) Research Limitations / Implications. Secondary-data reliance constrains causal attribution and excludes francophone/North African contexts. Field validation and financial modeling are recommended for future work. (5) Practical Implications. Policymakers and institutions can use this framework to pilot scalable, employment-linked hubs without constructing new campuses. (6) Originality / Value. This is the first study to align Africa-wide policy ambitions with operational design and costing of university-linked hub models.

title: Thermodynamic Justice in Space-Time: A Fluid Dynamics Framework for Haqq, Compensation, and Conscious Entropy Modulation

detail.title: Thermodynamic Justice in Space-Time: A Fluid Dynamics Framework for Haqq, Compensation, and Conscious Entropy Modulation
detail.abstract: Imagine the universe as a giant, invisible ocean where everything-planets, people, thoughts, and even fairness-moves like waves in water. This paper builds on a scientific idea that the universe, called "spacetime," acts like a fluid with push and flow, explaining gravity and time (Mudassir, 2025). We extend this to show how unfair actions, like stealing, create ripples of chaos in this ocean, which the universe naturally smooths out to restore fairness, or "haqq" (your rightful share in Islam). Your thoughts, like prayers, and actions, like charity, guide these waves to bring balance. We also explain mysterious things, like unseen forces (jinn) or the calming power of mosques, as patterns in this ocean. A real example of a delayed $23,000 payment shows how this works in life. Using simple language, we explain all terms, connect to Islamic ideas like prayer (salah) and patience (sabr), and suggest ways to test these ideas, like seeing if prayer reduces stress. This paper is for everyone-scientists, students, or anyone curious about how fairness and spirituality fit with science.

title: Opening call auction designs and price manipulation for price discovery: An experimental study

detail.title: Opening call auction designs and price manipulation for price discovery: An experimental study
detail.abstract: This study investigates how different opening call auction designs affect price discovery and manipulation through laboratory experiments. The first design replicates major stock exchange openings, allowing order placements and cancellations before announcing the opening price. We alternatively investigate two call auction designs in which traders are not allowed to cancel orders during the session, while the call auction time is divided into sub-periods and orders are executed every sub-period before the opening price is announced. We first demonstrate that allowing cancellations leads to price manipulation, while restricting them or introducing periodic clearings significantly reduces manipulative behavior. Second, we find a gradual price discovery process in economies with and prohibiting cancellations. However, price discovery can be quickly achieved in periodic clearings. These results indicate that price manipulations and longer non-trading minutes result in slower price discoveries. Third, we show that reinforcement learning, by which traders attempt to find profitable strategies from past performances, explains the order choices of our lab participants, and thus, price manipulations and price discovery. Lastly, we develop an equilibrium model of an opening call auction, which predicts uniform price discovery and trend-following strategies in all three designs, but experimental results reveal that real traders act more strategically and adaptively, improving price discovery and enabling manipulation absent in the model. We contribute to the literature by emphasizing the significant role of reinforcement learning on price manipulations and the price discovery process under different opening call auction designs. Our study has important policy implications regarding which call auction design is better for the opening call market.

title: Bank Leverage Restrictions in General Equilibrium: Solving for Sectoral Value Functions

detail.title: Bank Leverage Restrictions in General Equilibrium: Solving for Sectoral Value Functions
detail.abstract: This paper examines welfare effects of bank leverage restrictions. The Global Financial Crisis sparked rigorous debate on the appropriate leverage restriction to stabilize the banking sector without stunting it. I provide a methodological contribution for analyzing welfare effects of bank leverage ratio restrictions over the business cycle in a general equilibrium model with bank runs. This paper's contribution simplifies the model solution process, which is valuable given the model's realistic yet highly nonlinear and complex structure. detail.title: Do markets react to weather? Stock price reactions to weather alerts
detail.abstract: This paper examines the impact of weather alerts on stock prices. Using an event-study methodology, we show that the market responds negatively to weather alerts. This reaction is more pronounced when alerts indicate severe impact or involve multiple weather phenomena. Furthermore, firms operating in weather-sensitive industries as well as smaller, high-risk and high-growth firms listed on the junior growth market, experience significantly more negative stock returns. However, frequent updates about the alerts mitigate the negative market impact. Overall, the findings suggest that investors incorporate weather alerts into asset pricing, highlighting the importance of providing regular information during extreme weather events.

title: Introducing LCOAI: A Standardized Economic Metric for Evaluating AI Deployment Costs
affiliations: Blend Tiger

detail.title: Introducing LCOAI: A Standardized Economic Metric for Evaluating AI Deployment Costs
detail.abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) becomes foundational to enterprise infrastructure, organizations face growing challenges in accurately assessing the full economic implications of AI deployment. Existing metrics such as API token costs, GPU-hour billing, or Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) fail to capture the complete lifecycle costs of AI systems and provide limited comparability across deployment models. This paper introduces the Levelized Cost of Artificial Intelligence (LCOAI), a standardized economic metric designed to quantify the total capital (CAPEX) and operational (OPEX) expenditures per unit of productive AI output, normalized by valid inference volume. Analogous to established metrics like LCOE (levelized cost of electricity) and LCOH (levelized cost of hydrogen) in the energy sector, LCOAI offers a rigorous, transparent framework to evaluate and compare the cost-efficiency of vendor API deployments versus self-hosted, fine-tuned models. We define the LCOAI methodology in detail and apply it to three representative scenarios, OpenAI GPT-4.1 API, Anthropic Claude Haiku API, and a self-hosted LLaMA-2-13B deployment demonstrating how LCOAI captures critical trade-offs in scalability, investment planning, and cost optimization. Extensive sensitivity analyses further explore the impact of inference volume, CAPEX, and OPEX variability on lifecycle economics. The results illustrate the practical utility of LCOAI in procurement, infrastructure planning, and automation strategy, and establish it as a foundational benchmark for AI economic analysis. Policy implications and areas for future refinement, including environmental and performance-adjusted cost metrics, are also discussed.

detail.title: The Spillover Effects of Intellectual Property Theft: How Counterfeiting Accelerated China's Manufacturing Rise and Why Traditional Cost Estimates Are Grossly Undervalued
detail.abstract: This paper explores the pivotal role of intellectual property (IP) theft, particularly through counterfeiting, in propelling China's evolution from a producer of low-quality goods to a dominant force in global manufacturing, now accounting for approximately 30% of worldwide output. By synthesizing historical timelines, sector-specific alignments, economic quantifications, and recent 2025 data from sources like the OECD and USTR, we demonstrate how counterfeiting generated spillover benefits-including enhanced production volume, reverse engineering expertise, and iterative innovation-that accelerated China's industrial capabilities by an estimated 5-15 years in key sectors like electronics, batteries, apparel and footwear, pharmaceuticals, auto parts, and toys. Detailed case studies illustrate these dynamics, showing how illicit practices in each sector created hidden value ($50-200 billion per sector) through "learning by doing" and technology absorption, enabling transitions to legitimate dominance. Traditional valuations 2 of IP theft, which focus on direct revenue losses (e.g., $225-600 billion annually for the U.S.), grossly undervalue the harm by overlooking these spillovers, which amplify competitive advantages for the thief while imposing long-term economic displacements on victims, such as 2-5 million job losses in U.S. IP-intensive industries. Incorporating these effects could inflate global cost estimates by 2-3 times, reaching $1-3 trillion annually. The analysis draws implications for U.S. trade policy, suggesting escalated countermeasures like tariffs, reshoring incentives, and multilateral pressures to reclaim portions of the amplified losses. This study contributes to the literature by providing a comprehensive framework for assessing IP theft's dynamic impacts, with case studies offering granular evidence for policymakers.

detail.abstract: While the gap between private and public equity markets has been shrinking, the "disclosure gap" remains as wide as ever. We describe this disclosure gap, which we define as the difference between what has to be publicly disclosed in the two markets. Many believe the resulting status quo is optimal or close to it. We discuss three broad reasons why the status quo is in fact sub-optimal: agency problems in private equity which are comparable to those in public equity markets; poor outcomes including those resulting from "bankruptcy hardball"; and the free-riding advantage conferred on public markets. To address this we propose a modest level of mandatory public disclosure in private equity markets. They relate to Limited Partnership agreements, portfolio holdings, portfolio company accounts and return calculations. In each case the marginal financial cost of the proposed disclosure is negligible. We discuss possible objections to the proposals.

detail.abstract:
Objective: This study examines the internal financial determinants of profitability among UAE-listed real-estate developers. A balanced panel of 42 firm-year observations for the seven largest publicly traded companies (2019-2024) is analysed, with return on assets (ROA) as the dependent variable and leverage, liquidity, operational efficiency, and firm size as explanatory factors. A Hausman specification test favors a cross-section random-effects estimator. The chosen model explains 66 % of the variation in ROA (weighted R-squared = 0.66; adjusted = 0.62) and reveals that higher operational efficiency significantly enhances profitability while greater leverage exerts a pronounced negative effect. Liquidity and firm size are positive but not statistically significant. By controlling for unobserved firm-specific and time-invariant heterogeneity, the random-effects framework provides robust evidence that capital structure and asset-utilization efficiency are the primary internal drivers of performance in the UAE real-estate sector.

Findings: The analysis shows that stronger operational efficiency is positively associated with return on assets, while heavier leverage is linked to lower profitability. Liquidity and firm size, by contrast, do not display a statistically meaningful relationship with ROA. These results are broadly in line with recent evidence on Gulf real-estate developers and reflect the sector‚Äôs heavy reliance on debt finance and its dependence on effective asset use.

Contribution: For practitioners, the findings underline two priorities. First, improving how existing assets are deployed through tighter cost control, shorter project cycles, or better inventory management which offers a dependable route to higher returns. Second, monitoring capital structure is crucial: excessive borrowing can undermine performance even when market conditions appear favorable. In comparison, simply accumulating cash or pursuing scale for its own sake delivers no clear profitability benefit; growth and liquidity policies should therefore be guided by project-level economics rather than balance-sheet size alone.

detail.abstract: Insecurity remains one of the most pressing challenges undermining economic development in SouthEast Nigeria. This study focused on the post-2020 escalation of insecurity, marked by separatist agitations, sit-at-home orders, political unrest, targeted killings, and rising criminality. It explored the economic consequences of insecurity orchestrated by various actors and events specific to the region. The study examined six key themes: IPOB agitation, activities of the Eastern Security Network (ESN), attacks and assassinations by unknown gunmen, reprisal operations and abductions by government security forces, incidences of kidnapping, and attacks by killer herdsmen. A qualitative descriptive research design was adopted, utilizing thematic content analysis to examine data sourced from scholarly journals, media reports, government policy documents, NGO publications, and international development records. The study further employed SWOT and PESTEL frameworks to assess the strategic, social, political, and economic dimensions of insecurity and their implications for regional development. Findings revealed that insecurity has disrupted economic activity, weakened investor confidence, and constrained mobility and productivity across the SouthEast. While most forms of insecurity were found to negatively impact development, the activities of ESN appeared to offer localized protection in some areas. The study concludes that insecurity-if left unaddressed-will continue to hinder socioeconomic resilience in the region. It recommends a multi-stakeholder approach involving community engagement, institutional reform, and strategic policy interventions to restore peace and foster inclusive economic growth.

detail.abstract: Using Natural Language Processing, I develop a firm-level forward-looking measure of supply-side inflationary pressure based on firms‚Äô quarterly earnings conference call transcripts. detail.abstract: We investigate the use of path signatures in a machine learning context for hedging exotic derivatives under non-Markovian stochastic volatility models. detail.abstract: Record linkage, the process of identifying and linking records that refer to the same entity across different data sources, is a critical challenge in data management and integration. Exact matching often fails due to data entry errors, inconsistencies in representation, and missing information, necessitating fuzzy matching techniques. This paper describes a configurable and extensible fuzzy matching system developed as an asp .net core web api. The system allows users to define granular, field-wise matching strategies through external configuration, including the selection of various fuzzy string comparison algorithms, individual field weighting, and custom preprocessing logic for specific data types. It provides detailed match outputs, including overall similarity scores, Soundex comparisons, and per-field comparison details, facilitating transparency and iterative refinement of matching rules. We discuss the architecture, core matching engine, API design, and performance optimization strategies such as dynamic blocking for cross-recordset comparisons. The framework aims to provide a practical and adaptable solution for developers needing to integrate fuzzy record linkage capabilities into .NET applications.

detail.title: A practitioner's note about the antitrust community: A reflection of our economic and political system
detail.abstract: The antitrust community is the group of people whose profession involves competition law. The existence of a public policy dedicated to market competition is what brings this cross-border community together. It is composed of competition authorities, competition lawyers, economic consultants, judges, international organisations, scholars, and specialised media, besides legislators, market players, NGOs, arbitrators and litigation funders. Due to its informality and decentralised nature, the boundaries of this community (i.e., who is in and out) are not always clear, but various social aspects highlight its existence. From common jargons and regular gatherings to leading voices that serve as reference in the field, its existence is as true a social reality as other epistemic groups. However, the profile of its members is highly heterogeneous and the impact of their work to society is extremely significant, although commonly unnoticeable to the eyes of many. This note describes this community, identifies its members, and explains how it relates to the broader economic and political system in which it is inserted. The conclusion is that the community has been in therapy, as a result of its role as both catalyser and subject of macropolitical debates, despite the technical nature of the field.

detail.abstract: Ubuntu, an African moral philosophy centered on solidarity, voluntary cooperation, and fraternal human relations, is often mischaracterized as socialist. This paper refutes that claim, exposing the ideological distortion that arises from conflating Ubuntu‚Äôs humane and peaceful nature with socialism‚Äôs coercive, confiscatory, and statist foundations. Far from endorsing centralized control or forced redistribution, Ubuntu emphasizes voluntary fraternity and respect for individual dignity, rooted in the African worldview of harmony and nonaggression. By disentangling Ubuntu from foreign ideologies such as socialism‚Äîa viciously coercive and oppressive Western import‚Äîthis paper restores Ubuntu to its rightful place as a moral framework, not a political or economic doctrine underpinned by state aggression. The paper also highlights Africonomics as a more appropriate economic model for African societies, one that aligns with Ubuntu‚Äôs ethic of peace, natural rights, and voluntary cooperation.

detail.abstract: Historical growth is most commonly displayed in what are referred to here as typical growth charts, i.e., as a charted time series of the values of an investment from its purchase on a date in the past through subsequent dates up to the present. Unfortunately, such charts have a number of shortcomings that can severely limit their value as a means of providing investors with a comprehensive, integrated, and possibly unbiased view of historical performance. This is especially true when they are used for assessing relative investment growth. The present paper introduces another type of growth chart that avoids those shortcomings while providing a different but meaningful and perhaps better view of investment performance. When used either in lieu of or supplemental to typical growth charts, it can offer additional critical insights into historical performance to those who want to take such information into account when making investment decisions.

detail.abstract: Prospect theory, a mainstay model of behavioral economics, was designed by Kahneman and Tversky (1979) to offer a better descriptive account of human decision making than that provided by rational choice theory -- and in many instances, it seems to deliver on its originators' goal. Descriptions of plausible human behavior, then, should generally accord well with the features of prospect theory. The writings of William Shakespeare -- an acclaimed observer of humanity -- provide a classic data set of human behavior that can be tested for its adherence to prospect theory. This paper explores Shakespeare's works, finding that the main elements of prospect theory-reference point dependence, loss aversion, and asymmetric gain/loss risk preferences are well represented within the Shakespeare canon. A second branch of behavioral economics, that examining happiness or "subjective wellbeing," also is reviewed in light of Shakespeare's works. Finally, Adam Smith, another acclaimed observer of humanity (who lived a little bit closer to Shakespeare's time than to ours), offers some parallel behavioral commentary, too.

detail.title: Democratic Institutional Analysis: A Political Discretization Framework for Assessing Constitutional Governance
detail.abstract: This paper introduces "political discretization" as a comprehensive framework for systematically assessing democratic institutional health and detecting early signs of constitutional governance erosion. Political discretization-the systematic fragmentation of continuous democratic processes into controllable categorical units-represents a measurable pattern of institutional capture that operates across multiple domains from early Christian authority conflicts to contemporary regulatory capture and digital platform manipulation. Building on Max Weber's authority typology and contemporary neuroscientific research demonstrating how partisan identity suppresses analytical thinking, this framework provides empirical tools for measuring discourse fragmentation, authority substitution, cognitive conditioning, and alternative suppression in real-time. Unlike subjective assessments of democratic backsliding, this methodology enables evidence-based early warning systems through systematic measurement of institutional capture mechanisms. The framework integrates established research methodologies from political communication analysis, neural pathway studies of political cognition, and historical patterns of epistemological colonization to create comprehensive assessment instruments. These tools measure: (1) media discourse quality through automated text analysis and complexity preservation indices; (2) congressional oversight effectiveness through constitutional adherence and institutional independence metrics; (3) regulatory capture resistance through authority substitution and transparency assessments; and (4) democratic input preservation through citizen influence and alternative perspective protection measures. For practitioners, this research provides immediately implementable measurement protocols for government oversight bodies, civil society organizations, and international democracy support agencies. The framework enables systematic monitoring of democratic institutional health, early detection of capture patterns, and evidence-based intervention strategies. For academics, it offers novel theoretical synthesis bridging classical political theory with contemporary empirical research while providing robust methodological tools for cross-national comparative analysis. The framework's validation through historical back-testing, cross-domain pattern recognition, and integration with established research methodologies positions it as a foundational tool for protecting constitutional governance in an era of systematic institutional pressure. Rather than relying on crisis response or partisan interpretation, democratic societies can now proactively monitor and protect their institutions through systematic measurement and evidence-based intervention.

detail.title: Factors in the Illiquidity of Thinly Traded Securities
detail.abstract: We examine liquidity factors in light of modern market dynamics, focusing on liquidity across thinly versus actively traded securities. We explore whether the liquidity gap identified by the SEC is a byproduct of trading volume or a more complex response to evolving market factors such as market fragmentation, adverse selection, inventory costs, and competition. We find that liquidity components have asymmetric effects, with thinly traded securities facing significantly higher execution costs, latency, and temporal fragmentation compared to actively traded stocks. Market fragmentation, exacerbates these inefficiencies for low-activity stocks, as liquidity becomes more fragmented and execution times increase. Furthermore, we show that competition among exchanges benefits high-activity stocks but has a detrimental impact on the execution quality of low-activity stocks, leading to larger quoted spreads and slower executions. Our findings suggest that liquidity disparities are not simply a function of trading volume but also reflect the impact of modern market dynamics.

detail.abstract: This paper investigates whether textual density in corporate disclosures, proxied by the volume of machine-readable content in annual 10-K filings, predicts short-term stock returns. Using a comprehensive panel from 1994 through 2021, we sort firms into portfolios based on disclosure length and find that firms with higher information overload earn significantly lower returns in the subsequent month. The high-minus-low return spread ranges from ‚àí9.1% to ‚àí12.8% annually, controlling for standard risk factors. The effect is most pronounced among small-cap and growth firms, and in stocks with lower institutional ownership or belonging to disclosure-intensive industries. Our findings support the investor underreaction hypothesis, where information overload delays price adjustment, particularly where investor attention is limited. Robustness tests confirm that the effect is not subsumed by known factors. This study contributes to the asset pricing and disclosure literature by identifying a novel channel‚Äîdisclosure density as a priced friction in financial markets.

title: Defining Current and Expected Financial Constraints using AI: Reinterpreting the Cash Flow Sensitivity of Cash
affiliations: University of Birmingham - Birmingham Business School, University of Augsburg - Department of Economics, Durham University and University of Glasgow

detail.title: Defining Current and Expected Financial Constraints using AI: Reinterpreting the Cash Flow Sensitivity of Cash
detail.abstract: We propose a new approach to identify firm-level financial constraints by applying artificial intelligence to text of 10-K filings by U.S. public firms from 1993 to 2021. Leveraging transformer-based natural language processing, our model captures contextual and semantic nuances often missed by traditional text classification techniques, enabling more accurate detection of financial constraints. A key contribution is to differentiate between constraints that affect firms presently and those anticipated in the future. These two types of constraints are associated with distinctly different financial profiles: while firms expecting future constraints tend to accumulate cash preemptively, currently constrained firms exhibit reduced liquidity and higher leverage. We show that only firms anticipating financial constraints exhibit significant cash flow sensitivity of cash, whereas currently constrained and unconstrained firms do not. This calls for a narrower interpretation of this widely used cash-based constraints measure, as it may conflate distinct firm types-unconstrained and currently constrained-and fail to capture all financially constrained firms. Our findings underscore the critical role of constraint timing in shaping corporate financial behavior.

detail.abstract: Many high-income countries aim to both increase immigration in line with their labor market needs and decrease irregular arrivals, and some have explicitly promoted efforts to achieve the former as part of a solution to the latter. However, empirical evidence on how information about legal pathways shapes irregular migration intentions as well as self-selection and aspirations for mobility and qualification more broadly remains scant. We contribute new insights with a randomized controlled trial in rural Senegal, providing information and basic assistance on the U.S. Diversity Visa Lottery, which offers medium-and high-skilled migrants access to permanent residence. The intervention significantly increases migration intentions and shifts preferences toward legal pathways. However, currently ineligible individuals, particularly those already contemplating irregular migration, show increased interest in migrating irregularly, suggesting an unintended consequence of efforts to broadly promote legal migration options. Education aspirations only increase weakly from a high baseline. These aspirations already mostly surpass the requirements for pursuing a legal migration path, but participants are unable to realize them.

We then describe how the model can be used on a round-by-round basis to inform policy discussions by providing a structural narrative for forecast revisions.

title: The Right Amount of Competition in Mobile Telecommunication ‚Äì a Game Theoretic Framework
affiliations: Northwestern University - Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science and Northwestern University

detail.title: The Right Amount of Competition in Mobile Telecommunication ‚Äì a Game Theoretic Framework
detail.abstract:
Ensuring adequate competition in mobile telecommunication is a basic policy goal addressed by regulators such as the FCC when designing auction rules or approving secondary transactions. Ensuring adequate competition is also the basic question when anti-trust authorities review mergers, such as the ‚Äú4-to-3‚Äù merger in 2020 between Spring and T-Mobile in the U.S. A concern is that too much concentration can lead to a small number of firms exerting market power to decrease social welfare. However, in telecommunication, increased concentration may also lead to efficiency gains due to various scale effects. For example, Hazlett and Crandall (2024a) presents evidence that the Sprint/T-Mobile merger benefited consumers even though it led to fewer firms competing in the U.S. mobile market. This raises several basic questions. Does more concentration always benefit consumers and if not what effects determine the ‚Äúoptimal‚Äù number of competing firms in a market? How does this depend on the market size, the amount of bandwidth available or the scale effects that are at play?

In this work, we present a game theoretic framework to give insights into these questions. Our model is based on a framework for Cournot competition with congestion effects that has been used in a number of papers to study competition in wireless markets and other setting where users are sensitive to congestion effects. In these models, wireless service providers compete by determining a quantity of customers to serve. The price that they can then charge each customer is determined by a market clearing price as well as a congestion cost that depends on their spectrum holdings and the network infrastructure that they have deployed. This captures the fact the spectrum is a congestible resource and that customers care about quality of service so that they are not willing to pay as much for a network that offers a poorer quality of service. Our model captures several different scale effects. We account for the investment incentives of a service provider as a function of their bandwidth holdings, where a provider with more spectrum may see a larger return from investing in infrastructure. We also consider a congestion model that can capture ‚Äúmultiplexing gains‚Äù achieved by serving more users with proportionally more bandwidth. Finally, we also consider how operational cost may scale with an increasing number of users. We use this model to compare the economic welfare obtained under with different number of competing firms and different distributions of bandwidth. Our results show that the ‚Äúoptimal‚Äù number of firms can vary depending on these effects suggesting that policy makers need to carefully consider these effects when assessing competition.

detail.title: ASSESSING WI-FI EXHAUSTION AND SHORTFALLS IN WI-FI CAPACITY
detail.abstract: Wi-Fi is an essential component of modern connectivity and, therefore, of our modern economy. The vast majority of online activity traverses Wi-Fi networks, whether through mobile phones or through the diverse array of connected devices that permeate homes and businesses. Wi-Fi utilization is growing as our connected economy expands. As Wi-Fi utilization continues to expand, Wi-Fi congestion and ultimately ‚Äúexhaustion‚Äù becomes a constraint to growth. This is characterized by an insufficient amount of Wi-Fi spectrum which can degrade the quality and reliability of a user's Wi-Fi experience.  This paper has analyzed the conditions under which Wi-Fi congestion and Wi-Fi spectrum exhaustion is expected today and is likely to occur in the near future in the absence of allocating more spectrum for Wi-Fi.

detail.title: Socioeconomic and Geographic Determinants of Mexico‚Äôs Digital Divide
detail.abstract: This paper studies the demographic, socioeconomic, and geographic dimensions of Mexico‚Äôs digital divide at the state level using the Spatially Aware Technology Utilization Model. Using this model, associations between twenty-two dependent indicators of ICT access and purposeful internet use are posited with thirteen independent variables ‚Äì indicators of demographic, educational, economic, occupational attributes, technology training, and civil liberty. Geographic mapping reveals that there are considerable gaps and a clear north-south digital divide in Mexico, with coastal states and tourist hubs often leading the nation. K-means clustering reveals that very high to high levels of internet access and use clusters are in northern Mexican states of Baja California and Baja California Sur, and states bordering the U.S. The Federal District of Mexico including Ciudad de M√©xico (Mexico City), a hotspot of education and governance, has moderate level of internet access and use while the lowest levels are in central Mexico and southern states such as Guerrero, Oaxaca, and Chiapas. Regression analysis reveals that ICT access is positively associated with proportion of literate population age 15 and over. Internet use is inversely associated with young dependency ratio, positively associated with proportion of population which has received telecommunications training, and in some cases, with GDP per capita. Overall, these findings reinforce demographic and socioeconomic dimensions of Mexico‚Äôs digital divide. Based on these findings, Mexico can develop effective telecommunications policies to ensure equitable technology access and use, specifically to those in underserved states and communities.

detail.abstract: We examine whether overconfident bank CEOs attenuate or amplify risk exposure amid heightened economic policy uncertainty (EPU). Consistent with risk amplification channel, we find that banks led by overconfident CEOs exhibit nearly 9.1% higher risk during periods of high EPU relative to their peers. Further analyses suggest that overconfident CEOs fuel risk through aggressive credit extension and inadequate loan loss provisioning, leading to higher loan impairments and eroded bank performance

The model is part of a broader suite used to inform the monetary policy process at the Bank of England, and it can be used in a range of ways. In this paper, we explain how the model can be applied to produce structural decompositions, forecasts and counterfactual scenarios.

title: The Death of Distance: Internet and Political Trust in Africa

detail.title: The Death of Distance: Internet and Political Trust in Africa
detail.abstract: This paper shows that internet use reduces spatial disparities in political trust within Sub-Saharan African countries. We combine geocoded surveys across 17 countries (2013-2021) with mobile internet coverage data. First, we use a border discontinuity design comparing ethnic groups divided by national boundaries to show that remote citizens report higher political trust than those near capital cities. Then, we estimate how internet use interacts with distance from capital to affect political trust, adopting two instrumental variable strategies using 3G coverage and lightning strike frequency. We find that internet use reduces the distance trust relationship by cutting information costs. Remote citizens become more critical, aligning with opinions typically found near capitals. The effects are stronger in countries with high corruption and where governments capture traditional media. These changes translate into increased demand for political accountability and reduced electoral support for incumbents.

title: From Photon to Parliament: How Meaning Emerges in Biology and Infrastructure
affiliations: University of Birmingham

detail.title: From Photon to Parliament: How Meaning Emerges in Biology and Infrastructure
detail.abstract: This essay explores the emergence of meaning in two complex domains: biological perception and infrastructure governance. Beginning with the photon's journey through the visual system, we show how energy becomes experience through layered, adaptive processes. We then turn to infrastructure investment, where monetary inputs-like photons-must traverse social systems to yield meaning. Cost-benefit analysis (CBA) may measure value, but it cannot anticipate emergence. By comparing energy-to-meaning in biology with money-to-meaning in infrastructure, we reveal how complexity disrupts scalar currencies and demands a new politics-one attuned to history, coherence, and the dynamic construction of meaning.

detail.abstract: Motivated by game-theoretic models of crowd motion dynamics, this paper analyzes a broad class of distributed games with jump diffusions within the recently developed Œ±-potential games framework. We demonstrate that analyzing the Œ±-Nash equilibria is equivalent to solving finite-dimensional control problems. Beyond the viscosity and verification characterizations for the general games, we explicitly and in detail examine how spatial population distributions and interaction rules influence the structure of Œ±-Nash equilibria in these distributed settings, and in particular for crowd motion games. Our theoretical results are supported by numerical implementations using policy gradient-based algorithms, further demonstrating the computational advantages of the Œ±-potential game framework in computing Nash equilibria for general dynamic games.

detail.title: Law & Order: Rethinking Marcuse's Legacy for Abolitionist Politics
detail.abstract: This chapter offers a novel interpretation of an important phrase in Marcuse‚Äôs work: ‚Äúlaw and order.‚Äù For Angela Davis, Marcuse‚Äôs analysis of law and order reveals the importance of language for abolitionist politics. By contrast, I show that law and order, in Marcuse‚Äôs writings, generally refers to socially necessary repression. This reconceptualization of law and order harbors several important Marcusean insights for contemporary abolitionism. Crucially, it reveals that the abolitionist movement does not oppose law and order as such. Rather, its endeavor to supplant prisons and policing with life-affirming institutions means to transform the basic mechanisms of social repression, thereby realizing an emancipatory law and order. With Marcuse, we can recapture law and order from its conservative appropriation and restore it, as bequest, to our contemporary, abolitionist imaginary.

detail.title: Par for the Course: Did the Bank Term Funding Program (BTFP) Support Credit Intermediation?
detail.abstract: Regulators addressed the 2023 Regional Banking Crisis by using the systemic risk exception to back uninsured depositors and launching the Bank Term Funding Program (BTFP), which accepted eligible collateral at par without charging a penalty rates, effectively subsidizing banks with unrealized losses. We develop a design-based method to estimate BTFP's effect on credit intermediation. We find that BTFP loans replaced expensive deposits and mitigated potential credit collapses while adjusting credit composition between loans and commitments. Our findings highlight challenges of jointly analyzing banking crises and crisis-policy interventions and provide insights for designing future emergency lending and liquidity facilities.

detail.abstract: In recent times, the move towards globalization of accounting standards has been rapid. On the other hand, related accounting systems, like those for corporate laws, taxation laws, and capital market regulations, are still at the discretion of each country; hence, we do not expect material action towards their convergence globally. The purpose of this paper is to examine how financial accounting can be synchronized with these related systems in Japan, especially corporate laws, as the two have always been closely related. In this respect, we examined the experiences of other countries, particularly the U.S., the U.K. and France, since they are the most appropriate examples of how to deal with distributable profits reflecting international accounting standards like International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). We also discuss the effect of the possible change of treatment distributable profits under global accounting standards on behaviors of managements. Considering the financial environment, the Japanese government will need to emulate the European countries, seeking insights into the depth and breadth of the issues of the globalization of accounting standards and accounting principles of corporate laws. Thus, the experiences of other countries will be good examples for Japan in the coming future.

title: From the Meta-Vacuum to Consciousness: Informational Primacy and the Evolution of Reality's Structures
affiliations: Zhytomyr Polytechnic State University

detail.title: From the Meta-Vacuum to Consciousness: Informational Primacy and the Evolution of Reality's Structures
detail.abstract: This two-part article presents a radically new model of reality, grounded in the idea that information‚Äîrather than matter, energy, or even space-time‚Äîconstitutes the most fundamental substrate of existence. We begin with a conceptual shift: rather than treating the Big Bang as the ultimate beginning, we propose a deeper ‚Äúinformational rupture‚Äù in a preexisting ‚Äúmeta-vacuum‚Äù state, giving rise to multiple potential branches or phases of reality. One of these branches manifests as our familiar Universe, yet others may remain hidden or manifest indirectly via phenomena attributed to dark matter, dark energy, or quantum nonlocality. In Part One, we develop the axiomatic and mathematical foundations of this informational approach. We introduce a parametric space ŒõŒõ, an ‚Äúoperator control room‚Äù of informational states, and define how branches can emerge from phase transitions in the meta-vacuum. The standard physical laws‚Äîspace, time, fields, forces‚Äîare shown to be effective consequences of deeper informational processes. We also discuss how this viewpoint resonates with key ideas in quantum gravity, the holographic principle, and string theory. In Part Two, we explore how informational complexity evolves to generate higher levels of structure‚Äîleading from elementary particles and atoms to stars, galaxies, and biological life. Here, we propose that chemical, biological, and cognitive laws also arise as ‚Äúlayered‚Äù manifestations of the same informational foundation. Life and consciousness become natural outgrowths of informational dynamics, with each level introducing new effective principles that build upon (but do not contradict) underlying quantum and astrophysical laws. This model unifies multiple perspectives from quantum mechanics, cosmology, evolutionary biology, and cognitive science under a single principle of informational primacy. It suggests that physical laws, the emergence of life, the development of consciousness, and cultural evolution can be viewed as stages of continually increasing informational organization. Finally, we outline possible future directions, including toy-model simulations, connections to modern theories of quantum gravity, and interdisciplinary research bridging physics, information science, biology, and philosophy.

title: The Economic Impact of Instant Payments and Dollar-Linked Digital Currencies in the U.S

detail.title: The Economic Impact of Instant Payments and Dollar-Linked Digital Currencies in the U.S
detail.abstract: This paper examines the macroeconomic and financial implications of scaling instant payments in the United States, whether through public infrastructure or private alternatives such as stablecoins. While the transactional advantages of speed and cost reduction are well established, the broader economic consequences of real-time settlement remain underexplored. Focusing on high-value transactions such as B2B payments, this study investigates how accelerated settlement may affect liquidity, productivity, financial stability, inflation, fiscal enforcement, and fraud exposure. Drawing on international case studies, economic theory, and original quantitative estimates, the analysis finds that settlement delays currently immobilize up to $3.4 trillion in working capital. This generates an estimated opportunity cost of $171 billion per day, borne primarily by businesses in the form of short-term financing costs to bridge payment lags. Additionally, the paper estimates that long-term displacement of card-based payments by lower-cost instant payment methods may affect inflation dynamics and reduce consumer prices by 0.11 to 0.56 percentage points, depending on instant payment adoption and market structure. While these projections highlight material economic effects, they warrant further empirical validation. The analysis also underscores the importance of mitigating emerging risks such as financial fraud. The paper concludes with policy recommendations for U.S. regulators, emphasizing the need for interoperability, institutional mandates, and infrastructure investment to unlock the full economic benefits of instant payments.

title: The Electoral Consequences of Natural Disasters: A Dynamic Fixed-Effects Analysis

detail.title: The Electoral Consequences of Natural Disasters: A Dynamic Fixed-Effects Analysis
detail.abstract: With the increasing frequency of major natural disasters, understanding their political consequences is of paramount importance for democratic accountability. The existing literature is deeply divided, with some studies finding that voters punish incumbents for disaster-related damages, while others find they reward them for relief efforts. This paper investigates the electoral consequences of natural disasters for incumbent mayors, broader electoral dynamics, and the long-term political ambition of officeholders. The study leverages a comprehensive panel dataset of over 10,000 candidate-election observations in U.S. mayoral races from 1989 to 2021, combining detailed election data with a global registry of disaster events. To identify causal effects, the analysis employs a robust dynamic two-way fixed-effects event-study design, validated by extensive pre-trend and placebo tests. The findings reveal that the electoral impact of disasters is highly conditional on their timing. A disaster that strikes in the same quarter as an election provides a significant electoral boost to incumbents, increasing their vote share by over 6 percentage points. However, disasters consistently suppress voter turnout, reducing it by an average of 1.4 percentage points. In a novel finding, the analysis demonstrates that the experience of managing a disaster significantly increases an incumbent's likelihood of seeking re-election in the subsequent cycle by as much as 12 percentage points. These findings help reconcile conflicting theories of retrospective voting by highlighting the critical role of voter myopia and salience. They also reveal a previously undocumented channel through which crises shape political careers, suggesting that disaster management is not only a test of governance but also a catalyst for political ambition.

Using German tax return data, we show that only a small fraction of entrepreneurs opt for corporate taxation, despite substantial potential tax savings. A pre-registered incentivized online experiment demonstrates that complexity aversion, status quo bias, and misperception about the corporate tax burden‚Äîarising from the interaction of corporate and deferred dividend taxation‚Äîhelp explain the preference for partnership taxation. detail.title: The Politics of Nostalgia: How Digital Media Revives, Reinvents, and Polarises National Memory in India
detail.abstract: This paper explores the complex role of nostalgia in shaping national memory in contemporary India, with a particular focus on how digital media platforms amplify, reinvent, and polarise historical narratives. Drawing on cultural memory studies, media theory, and recent examples from social media, the paper argues that nostalgia is neither inherently conservative nor progressive, but rather functions as a contested space where multiple identities and political agendas converge. In the Indian context, digital nostalgia surfaces in diverse forms: from romanticised portrayals of ancient empires to grassroots rediscoveries of neglected regional figures and communities. While such narratives can foster cultural pride and inclusivity, they can equally fuel exclusionary identity politics and historical grievance. The study shows how algorithmic amplification and emotionally charged content simplify complex histories into shareable, polarised stories, contributing to both empowerment and division. Ultimately, the paper suggests that nostalgia, when critically engaged, can serve not only as a bridge to the past but also as a tool for a more reflective national conversation about belonging, history, and identity.

detail.abstract: This research paper explores the hidden drivers of financial success among Eritrean migrants navigating uncertainty, displacement, and limited institutional access. Drawing on original survey data collected from diaspora communities across East African host countries. I apply a mixed-methods framework combining ordinal and binary logistic regression, random forest classification, bootstrapping, and Bayesian causal mediation; to identify the structural and cultural variables most predictive of financial stability. The findings reveal that participation in Ekub, a traditional rotating savings association, and engagement in communal support systems are the strongest predictors of financial success, outperforming conventional factors such as age, education, or employment status. A bidirectional mediation model confirms that Ekub and community trust reinforce one another, forming a resilient economic infrastructure rooted in shared obligation and interdependence. Interpreting these patterns through historical, behavioral, and cultural lenses, the study invites a rethinking of individualistic assumptions in mainstream economic theory. It suggests that migrant resilience may be better understood not as personal perseverance, but as a structured, inherited system of trust, discipline, and communal logic.

The location of a production plant in France has consequences throughout the value chain. detail.abstract:
This comprehensive research paper presents an extensive quantitative analysis of the Nifty 50 index's weekly behavioral patterns spanning a decade from 2015 to 2025, with specific focus on price movements from Friday market open to the subsequent Thursday market close. The study establishes a robust statistical foundation for developing systematic weekly option selling strategies in the rapidly evolving Indian derivatives market. Through rigorous examination of over 470 weekly trading cycles encompassing various market conditions including bull markets, bear markets, and periods of extreme volatility, this research identifies consistent and exploitable patterns in index behavior. The analysis reveals that approximately 70% of weekly movements fall within ¬±300 points of the Friday opening price, while extreme movements exceeding ¬±700 points occur in only 5.3% of weeks, providing strong statistical support for strategic options positioning. The study employs sophisticated statistical methodologies including distribution analysis, volatility clustering examination, and extreme value theory to develop a comprehensive understanding of weekly price behavior. The findings inform the development of a rules-based options selling strategy that systematically capitalizes on time decay (theta) while implementing multi-layered risk management protocols through data-driven strike price adjustments and dynamic stop-loss mechanisms.

The research demonstrates the strategy's potential for generating consistent passive income within clearly defined risk parameters, with theoretical returns significantly exceeding traditional fixed-income investments. The empirical evidence supports the viability of systematic options selling approaches when implemented with appropriate discipline and risk management safeguards. This study contributes significantly to the academic literature on systematic trading strategies and provides practical insights for both retail and institutional traders seeking to exploit the structural characteristics of weekly options in emerging market derivatives. The findings offer valuable guidance for evidence-based derivative trading decisions and establish a benchmark for future research in this rapidly expanding field.

detail.abstract: As generative artificial intelligence reshapes the conditions of knowledge production, public education faces an epistemological crisis: students are increasingly trained to retrieve answers, yet lack the tools to interrogate the process of knowing itself. This paper argues that epistemology-the philosophical study of knowledge-must be reintegrated into the educational core as both a conceptual and practical literacy. Drawing on critical theory, especially the work of Slavoj ≈Ωi≈æek, as well as cognitive science and curriculum studies, the paper examines how prompt-based AI systems simulate inquiry while concealing the ideological and epistemic assumptions they encode. The analysis traces the erosion of epistemic agency in contemporary classrooms and proposes a curricular framework that positions epistemology as a foundation for critical thinking, democratic resilience, and philosophical inquiry in the age of machine knowledge.

detail.abstract: This paper examines the impact of multiple regulatory constraints on the financing of the economy in the context of the implementation of the Basel III regulation on capital and liquidity. We propose a simple theoretical model of bank lending decision to analyse the interactions between these various regulatory requirements and the conditions under which some constraints may bind while others may not. Building on the predictions of this theoretical model, we estimate the impact of these different regulatory requirements on lending growth, on a panel of 54 French banks since 2014. Our results indicate that four pairwise interactions, most of them involving the leverage ratio, have a significant effect on lending growth. We also emphasize that the regulatory ratios interact more for banks with lower regulatory ratios and in periods of financial stress. More specifically, our results highlight a significant relationship of partial substitutability between the leverage ratio, the LCR and the NSFR for such banks in such periods, resulting from the positive effect of bank own funds on liquidity.

detail.abstract: This study investigates how variability in research topics influences the evolutionary dynamics of scientific and technological fields, offering strategic insights for innovation management and technological forecasting. By applying entropy measures and variance decomposition, we analyze four emerging quantum domains-quantum optics, metrology, imaging, and sensing-to quantify the diversity and stability of their research trajectories. Our findings reveal that quantum optics exhibits lower variability and more stable developmental paths (entropy H = 0.83), while quantum sensing demonstrates higher variability and uncertainty (H = 0.93), indicating divergent evolutionary patterns. Variance analysis shows that 91.7% of the observed variability occurs within fields rather than between them, underscoring internal topic diversity as a critical driver of scientific and technological evolution. This suggests that variability is not merely noise but a structural feature that shapes the direction and pace of innovation. These insights have significant implications for technological forecasting. Fields characterized by high variability may signal earlystage, exploratory dynamics with multiple competing paradigms, requiring flexible and adaptive forecasting models. Conversely, low-variability fields may reflect more mature trajectories, where trend extrapolation and exploitation strategies can be more reliable. From a strategic perspective, our results suggest that innovation strategies should be aligned with the variability profile of the target field: exploratory approaches are better suited for high-entropy domains, while exploitative strategies can effectively support incremental innovation in low-entropy areas. This study contributes to the theoretical understanding of scientific evolution and provides actionable guidance for R&D managers, foresight analysts, and policymakers seeking to allocate resources, design innovation portfolios, and anticipate technological shifts in emerging quantum technologies.

detail.abstract: The conventional understanding of stability, order, and progress often centers on permanence and linear growth. Yet, across every observable scale of existence‚Äîfrom the quantum foam to the grand cosmic expanse‚Äîa paradoxical principle appears to govern the very essence of cohesion, evolution, and systemic ‚Äúlearning‚Äù: Adaptive order from inherent f lux. This principle posits that complex systems establish their enduring integrity and evolve their capabilities through the continuous shedding, transformation, and self governing renewal of their components. This project aims to articulate this pervasive yet often elusive universal principle. Despite its fundamental role in the universe‚Äôs operation, its overarching nature remains obscured for several critical reasons: operation at unseen layers, challenging deeply ingrained linear perceptions, obscurity by disciplinary silos, and misinterpretation of dissolution as an endpoint rather than a necessary catalyst for regeneration and optimization. By developing a comprehensive conceptual framework that details how this principle manifests across cosmic, biological, social, and technological domains, this project seeks to generate new research questions and create a compelling narrative that fosters interdisciplinary discussion. The goal is to illuminate this universal principle, revealing how apparent destruction or decay is, in fact, an indispensable mechanism for generating emergent properties, fostering resilience, and enabling long term systemic vitality.

detail.title: Biar Lambat Asal Selamat: The Slow But Safe Twenty-Five Year Recalibration of Personal Bankruptcy in Malaysia
detail.abstract: A popular Malay proverb advises, ‚Äúlet it be slow, as long as it is safe‚Äù (biar lambat asal selamat). The phrase aptly characterizes the quarter-century, multistage evolution of personal bankruptcy in Malaysia. That process culminated in late 2023 with reforms that mirror those in neighboring Singapore and many other more distant countries. Malaysian bankruptcy law has long included a very limited debt discharge, but as it left more and more economically debilitated debtors in perpetual bankruptcy limbo, policymakers became dissatisfied with leaving a huge and growing mass of debtors to languish. In 1998, they began taking a series of hesitant steps to alleviate the flow of cases into and, more importantly, accelerate the exit of cases out of the bankruptcy system. Eighteen months of empirical data on the effects of this revolution in Malaysian bankruptcy policy now reveal the important but limited effects of this process of entry and exit recalibration. The halting series of legislative and regulatory changes and consequent empirical results in Malaysia from 1999 to 2025 are enlightening as to the purpose and (in)effectiveness of various ‚Äúsafe‚Äù approaches to reducing the incidence of personal bankruptcy and expanding discharge relief. This article reveals those lessons. It also reveals the motivations for these monumental shifts in Malaysian bankruptcy policy, with a closer look at the nuanced role of Islamic law and individual religious conviction in a modern democratic majority-Muslim state.

detail.abstract: This paper investigates the complex interplay between inflation and consumer behavior, emphasizing how rising prices affect purchasing decisions and broader economic trends. The literature review identifies several critical factors that influence consumer spending patterns during inflationary periods, such as increased price sensitivity, shifts in brand loyalty, and the psychological effects of economic uncertainty. Research findings indicate that inflation significantly alters consumer decision-making, particularly impacting low-income households that face the brunt of price hikes on essential goods .The study reveals that consumers adopt a more strategic shopping approach, focusing on value and engaging in careful planning to counteract the adverse effects of inflation on their purchasing power. Furthermore, it highlights the role of purchasing power as a vital determinant of consumer spending, suggesting that government assistance and reliance on credit can help maintain spending levels even in the face of rising unemployment.Additionally, the paper underscores the necessity of incorporating psychological factors into economic analyses, as emotional reactions to inflation can lead to significant changes in spending, saving, and investment behaviors. By exploring these dynamics, the research aims to provide essential insights for policymakers and businesses striving to address the challenges posed by inflation and to formulate effective strategies that resonate with consumer concerns. Ultimately, this study enhances the understanding of how inflation influences consumer behavior and its broader implications for economic stability.

detail.abstract: This paper examines the structural and systemic risks posed by the rise of collateralized loan obligations (CLOs) and private equity (PE) leverage, drawing explicit parallels with the collateralized debt obligations (CDOs) that fueled the 2008 financial crisis. Through a comprehensive review of academic literature, regulatory reports, and empirical data, the study highlights how covenant-lite loans, declining underwriting standards, and increased cross-institutional exposures have created an opaque and potentially fragile credit ecosystem. The paper introduces a detailed scenario analysis simulating a severe monetary tightening shock, revealing potential contagion pathways from leveraged PE-backed companies to CLO tranches and institutional investors. Empirical data visualizations-including trends in global CLO issuance, the growth of covenant-lite loans, and the exponential rise in PE assets under management-reinforce the argument that these markets are more interconnected and systemically significant than widely recognized. The findings suggest that while CLO and PE markets have enabled broader capital formation, they also carry underappreciated risks that could transform localized credit shocks into global financial instability. The paper concludes by proposing policy and regulatory enhancements aimed at strengthening disclosure, improving stress testing frameworks, and reducing reliance on fragile capital structures.

detail.abstract: This study investigates the impact of dragon fruit cultivation on income generation, profitability, and employment among farm households in Bangladesh, focusing on Jhenaidah and Chuadanga districts. As a recently introduced high-value crop, dragon fruit offers significant economic potential due to its adaptability, nutritional value, and strong market demand. Utilizing a mixed-method approach, primary data were collected from 160 dragon fruit farmers through structured household surveys. The Cobb-Douglas production function was employed to assess input-output relationships, revealing that labor, land preparation, seedlings, and fertilizer significantly influence income, with labor showing the highest elasticity (0.772). The estimated R-squared (0.898) suggests that the model explains a substantial portion of income variability. Cost-benefit analysis indicates a high benefitcost ratio (1.83), confirming strong profitability. Furthermore, dragon cultivation contributes to increased labor force participation and reduced dependency ratios. Average daily working hours rose by 2.13, and full-time employment increased by over 7 days per month, indicating a shift from seasonal to year-round employment. These findings highlight the socioeconomic benefits of dragon fruit cultivation and suggest that it is a viable tool for rural development. The study recommends supportive policies, input optimization, infrastructure investment, and market linkage to further enhance the profitability and sustainability of dragon fruit farming in Bangladesh.

detail.title: Quantlet: The Code Snippet Knowledge Platform
detail.abstract: Many researchers increasingly rely on code snippets, algorithms, and information they find online to address complex problems. While these resources can provide immediate solutions, they often come from unverified sources and lack the context necessary for correct application. This growing dependence on readily available, sometimes ill-advised, information can lead to significant missteps, including inefficient code, flawed methodologies, or incorrect conclusions. As a result, researchers may unwittingly propagate errors or overlook more robust, appropriate solutions that are crucial for scientific progress. This paper presents the integration of the Quantlet and Quantinar platforms, collectively referred to as the Q2 ecosystem, aimed at overcoming challenges faced by applied scientists and researchers due to the vast and fragmented array of data and code available online. The focus of this integration is to enhance accessibility and usability of academic resources by effectively linking research with pertinent code and datasets. The study introduces an adaptive clustering algorithm that organizes and dynamically groups academic content from Quantinar alongside code and computational results from Quantlet, thus linking academic theory and practice. With these technical advancements, the Q2 framework aspires to enhance transparency and reproducibility within the academic research landscape. Ultimately, it aims to provide a cohesive learning environment that meets the evolving needs of the academic community, empowering researchers in their pursuit of knowledge and facilitating deeper insights into complex data-driven methodologies.

A total of 160 child beggars were interviewed for this study. Data was obtained from respondents utilizing a well-organized questionnaire. An interview schedule, and face-to-face interview methods were used for collecting primary data. We employed simple random sampling techniques. Various socioeconomic and demographic variables were taken into account during data collection. However, only variables relating to education, health, and living Standards are used in this work. According to the study, around 54.4% of child beggars were illiterate, and 38.8% of child beggars did not attend school. The vast majority of respondents (67.5%) did not associate any type of labor other than begging. Over half of the child beggars (61.3%) have reported playing with friends in their spare time. Around 65.7% of respondents were subjected to various forms of torture, with beatings being the most common. Food consumption was insufficient, and the majority of them were underweight. Their sanitary conditions were deplorable, and as a result, they suffered from a variety of mild to severe diseases. But, most importantly, about 63.1% of them were using tube-well water as their main source of drinking water.

detail.title: Commodity trading: Evidence from traders' profits and an executive survey
detail.abstract: In this paper, we examine the sources of trading profits, with focus on commodity traders. We look at the trading business models for both commodity hedge funds and merchant traders, which we define together as commodity traders, albeit their different underlying business models. We document that hedge funds generate much of their trading returns from carrying metal, energy, and agriculture commodity risk in their books. Second, we find that hedge funds make use of commodity time series momentum phenomenon. In our regression, we obtain a ùëÖ2 of 0.43 when explaining Eurekahedge's monthly commodity hedge fund index's returns on commodity futures' returns and momentum. We show also that hedge funds make their highest returns at times when there is large cross-sectional withinindustry variability in industrial firms' profit margins. Next, we document that merchant traders also thrive in periods of economic turbulence. Merchant traders make returns from building real options that pay off in volatile times, when short-horizon commodity price volatility is high, and when the many industries' supply and demand balances are out of equilibrium. In a panel regression, using commodity futures' price volatilities and a measure of aggregate supply demand imbalance in the economy, we can explain 41% of the time variation in nine of the leading merchant traders' annual profits. Finally, we present data from an executive survey related to perceived trading opportunities, that supports our other findings on the drivers of trading profits. In the cross-section of industries, the executives view trading opportunities to be higher in industries with high economic uncertainty.

detail.abstract: Financial distress is widespread in European soccer, posing systemic risks that extend beyond individual clubs. A critical externality arises when insolvent teams are replaced by less competitive entrants, reducing overall league quality and social welfare. We develop a theoretical model that formalizes this mechanism and shows how UEFA's Financial Fair Play (FFP) regulations can enhance welfare by internalizing the externality. Using granular data on over 8,900 player transfers across 20 European leagues (2015-2023) and controlling for player characteristics, we document that cross-transfers-bilateral player exchanges-are associated with capital gains that are 37% higher than standard transfers. This finding illustrates how regulations designed to improve market stability can paradoxically incentivize creative accounting practices, exemplifying the broader phenomenon of regulatory offset effects.

detail.abstract: The rising burden of student debt calls for a reassessment of the economic returns to postsecondary education. This study estimates net returns to a range of educational credentials by integrating actual student loan payments into post-completion earnings. Leveraging linked administrative data on postsecondary enrollment and credit records, we examine outcomes for over 22,000 individuals. Using a matched difference-in-differences framework, pairing degree completers with non-completers from the same institution's metropolitan area, major, and enrollment cohort, we estimate the causal impact of credential completion on earnings net of student loan payments. We define loan-adjusted income as gross annual earnings minus observed student loan payments. On average, loan payments account for 23% of gross earnings premium in the years following completion, though this burden declines over time. Despite these costs, we find that postsecondary credentials yield substantial net earnings gains, reinforcing higher education as a worthwhile investment. We close with a discussion of implications for student loan and higher education policies.

This paper proposes a new unified accounting framework to measure Global Supply Chain (GSC) activities. detail.abstract: We study a pumped hydro energy storage facility that consists of two interconnected reservoirs-an upper and a lower-where one reservoir may be fed by natural inflow. The system operator makes real-time decisions regarding the amount of water to pump or release, thereby determining the amount of electricity to buy from or sell to the market. detail.abstract:
This paper examines how entrepreneurs strategically design experiments to convince venture capitalists (VCs) to fund their projects when investors interpret data through heterogeneous statistical frameworks. Drawing on Liang (2021)'s model of games with incomplete information played by statistical learners, we translate her abstract theoretical framework into a practical venture capital setting. We characterise how entrepreneurs balance funding plausibility against equity dilution by strategically choosing experiments along two critical dimensions: sample size (precision) and dimensionality (breadth of metrics). Our analysis reveals that for genuinely high-quality projects, increased precision helps by forcing VC beliefs to converge toward true quality. For low-quality projects, funding depends on preserving disagreement through sparse, high-dimensional experiments. The entrepreneur's optimal design depends critically on their prior beliefs: confident entrepreneurs choose high-precision, low-dimensional experiments that minimise equity dilution, while uncertain entrepreneurs opt for sparse, high-dimensional experiments that maximise the probability some VC will hold sufficiently optimistic beliefs. The framework provides a rigorous foundation for understanding how entrepreneurs and investors can rationally disagree when observing identical evidence, with significant implications for strategic information design in entrepreneurial settings.
